<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading">Russo-Ukrainian War</h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Ongoing war in Eastern Europe since 2014</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the war ongoing since 2014. For the recent escalation, see <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>. For other wars between the two nations, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_between_Russia_and_Ukraine" title="List of wars between Russia and Ukraine">List of wars between Russia and Ukraine</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r963460841">@media all and (min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .desktop-float-right{box-sizing:border-box;float:right;clear:right}}.mw-parser-output .infobox.vevent .status>p:first-child{margin:0}</style><table class="infobox vevent" style="width:25.5em;border-spacing:2px;"><tbody><tr><th class="summary" colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">Russo-Ukrainian War</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="background-color:#DCDCDC;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;">Part of the <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_conflicts" title="Post-Soviet conflicts">post-Soviet conflicts</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;line-height:1.5em;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg"><img alt="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.svg" data-file-height="1478" data-file-width="2199" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg/300px-2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg/450px-2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg/600px-2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a><br/>The military situation as of 28 June 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russo-Ukrainian_War&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, during the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a><br/><div style="float:left;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#E3D975; color:black;"> </span> Controlled by Ukraine</span></div><br/><div style="float:left;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#EBC0B3; color:black;"> </span> Occupied by Russia and pro-Russian forces</span></div>
<p><br/>
</p>
<small>For a more detailed map, see the <a href="/wiki/Template:Russo-Ukrainian_War_detailed_map" title="Template:Russo-Ukrainian War detailed map">Russo-Ukrainian War detailed map</a></small></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><table style="width:100%;margin:0;padding:0;border:0;display:inline-table"><tbody><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Date</th><td>20 February 2014<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[b]</a></sup>  present<br/>(8 years, 4 months, 4 weeks and 1 day)
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>: 24 February 2022  present<br/>(4 months, 3 weeks and 4 days)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Location</th><td><div class="location"><a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Millerovo_air_base_attack" title="Millerovo air base attack">spillover</a> into <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>)</div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Status</th><td class="status">
<a href="/wiki/List_of_ongoing_armed_conflicts" title="List of ongoing armed conflicts">Ongoing</a></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Territorial<br/>changes</th><td>
<p>Changes prior to 2022 invasion:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by Russia</a></li>
<li>Occupation of the <a href="/wiki/Kherson_Oblast" title="Kherson Oblast">Kherson Oblast</a> portion of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crimean_peninsula" title="Crimean peninsula">Crimean peninsula</a> (<a href="/wiki/Strilkove" title="Strilkove">Strilkove</a>) from March to December 2014</li>
<li>Pro-Russian forces control the eastern <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a></li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">Belligerents</th></tr><tr><td style="width:50%;border-right:1px dotted #aaa;">
<div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/23px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/35px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/45px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a></li></ul>
</div>
<hr/>
For countries supporting Ukraine during the 2022 invasion, see <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine#Foreign_military_involvement" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a></td><td style="width:50%;padding-left:0.25em">
<div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia"><img alt="Russia" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic"><img alt="Donetsk People's Republic" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg/23px-Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg/35px-Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg/45px-Flag_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">Donetsk People's Republic</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic"><img alt="Luhansk People's Republic" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">Luhansk People's Republic</a></li></ul>

<div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; font-size: 100%; text-align: left;"><div>Supported by</div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; text-align: left; list-style: none none; margin-left: 0;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Flag_of_Belarus.svg/23px-Flag_of_Belarus.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Flag_of_Belarus.svg/35px-Flag_of_Belarus.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Flag_of_Belarus.svg/46px-Flag_of_Belarus.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> (since 2022)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[a]</a></sup>
</li></ul>
</div>

</div></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">Strength</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<div style="float: left;"><i>For details of strengths and units involved at key points in the war, see:</i></div>

<div class="plainlist"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine"><img alt="Ukraine" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/23px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/35px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/45px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> Ukraine and allies
<ul><li>4,619 killed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[8]</a></sup></li>
<li>9,70010,700 wounded<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OHCHR_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-OHCHR-11">[9]</a></sup></li>
<li>70 missing<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup></li>
<li>2,768 captured<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[13]</a></sup></li>
<li>300+ <a href="/wiki/T-64" title="T-64">T-64</a> tanks<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[14]</a></sup></li></ul>
</div></td><td style="width:50%;padding-left:0.25em">
<div class="plainlist"><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia"><img alt="Russia" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> Russia and allies
<ul><li>5,768 killed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OHCHR_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-OHCHR-11">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[c]</a></sup></li>
<li>12,70013,700 wounded<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OHCHR_11-2"><a href="#cite_note-OHCHR-11">[9]</a></sup></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-top:1px dotted #aaa;">
<p><b>Civilian casualties:</b><br/>
3,393 killed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup><br/>
7,0009,000 wounded<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OHCHR_11-3"><a href="#cite_note-OHCHR-11">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
See <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> for casualties resulting from the 2022 invasion.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1061467846">.mw-parser-output .navbox{box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid .sidebar-pretitle-with-top-image,.mw-parser-output .sidebar-caption{padding:0.2em 0.4em 0;line-height:1.2em}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-pretitle{padding:0.4em 0.4em 0;line-height:1.2em}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-title,.mw-parser-output .sidebar-title-with-pretitle{padding:0.2em 0.8em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em}.mw-parser-output .mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:100%!important;clear:both;float:none!important;margin-left:0!important;margin-right:0!important}}</style><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks vcard hlist"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title" style="background:#white;"><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Russo-Ukrainian War</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War"><img alt="Russo-Ukrainian War Flag.svg" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="133" style="background:#FADA5E;">
Major events</th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<ul><li>Events in 20132014
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">Pro-Russian unrest</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Historical_background_of_the_2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="Historical background of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">Historical background</a></li></ul></li>

</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background:#FADA5E;">

Related topics</th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="UkrainianSoviet War">UkrainianSoviet War</a></li>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2014_anti-war_protests_in_Russia" title="2014 anti-war protests in Russia">2014</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_foreign_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="List of foreign aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War">Foreign aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Template:Russo-Ukrainian War"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Template talk:Russo-Ukrainian War"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Russo-Ukrainian_War&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Russo-Ukrainian War</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[d]</a></sup> is an ongoing war between <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (together with <a href="/wiki/Russian_separatist_forces_in_Donbas" title="Russian separatist forces in Donbas">pro-Russian separatist forces</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[e]</a></sup> It was started by Russia in February 2014 following the Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a>, and initially focused on the status of <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" title="Donbas">Donbas</a>, internationally recognised as part of Ukraine. The first eight years of the conflict included the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russian annexation of Crimea</a> (2014) and the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas_(2014%E2%80%932022)" title="War in Donbas (20142022)">war in Donbas</a> (2014present) between Ukraine and Russian-backed separatists, as well as <a href="/wiki/List_of_Black_Sea_incidents_involving_Russia_and_Ukraine" title="List of Black Sea incidents involving Russia and Ukraine">naval incidents</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Ukrainian_cyberwarfare" title="RussianUkrainian cyberwarfare">cyberwarfare</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="RussiaUkraine relations">political tensions</a>. Following a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932022_Russo-Ukrainian_crisis" title="20212022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis">Russian military build-up</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_border" title="RussiaUkraine border">RussiaUkraine border</a> from late 2021, the conflict expanded significantly when Russia launched <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">a full-scale invasion of Ukraine</a> on 24 February 2022.
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests and <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">a revolution</a> resulting in the removal of pro-Russian President <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> in February 2014, <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">pro-Russian unrest</a> erupted in parts of Ukraine. Russian <a href="/wiki/Little_green_men_(Russo-Ukrainian_War)" title="Little green men (Russo-Ukrainian War)">soldiers without insignia</a> took control of strategic positions and infrastructure in the Ukrainian territory of Crimea, and <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_the_Crimean_Parliament" title="Capture of the Crimean Parliament">seized the Crimean Parliament</a>. Russia organized <a href="/wiki/2014_Crimean_status_referendum" title="2014 Crimean status referendum">a controversial referendum</a>, whose outcome was for Crimea to join Russia. This led to the annexation of Crimea. In April 2014, demonstrations by pro-Russian groups in the Donbas escalated into a war between the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine" title="Armed Forces of Ukraine">Armed Forces of Ukraine</a> and Russian-backed separatists of the self-declared <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">Donetsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">Luhansk</a> republics.
</p><p>In August 2014, unmarked Russian military vehicles crossed the border<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[19]</a></sup> into the Donetsk republic. An undeclared war began between Ukrainian forces on one side, and separatists intermingled with Russian troops on the other, although Russia attempted to hide its involvement. The war settled into a <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">static conflict</a>, with repeated failed attempts at a ceasefire. In 2015, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minsk_II" title="Minsk II">Minsk II</a> agreements were signed by Russia and Ukraine, but a number of disputes prevented them being fully implemented. By 2019, 7% of Ukraine was classified by the Ukrainian government as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporarily_occupied_territories_of_Ukraine" title="Temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine">temporarily occupied territories</a>.
</p><p>In 2021 and early 2022, there was a major Russian military build-up around Ukraine's borders. <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> accused Russia of planning an invasion, which it denied. Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> criticized the <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_NATO" title="Enlargement of NATO">enlargement of NATO</a> as a threat to his country and demanded Ukraine be barred from ever <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="UkraineNATO relations">joining the military alliance</a>. He also expressed <a href="/wiki/Russian_irredentism" title="Russian irredentism">irredentist</a> views, questioned Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Right_to_exist" title="Right to exist">right to exist</a>, and falsely stated that Ukraine was established by <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putin_Ukraine_statehood_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Putin_Ukraine_statehood-25">[20]</a></sup> On 21 February 2022, Russia officially recognised the two <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">self-proclaimed separatist states</a> in the Donbas, and openly sent troops into the territories. Three days later, Russia invaded Ukraine. Much of the international community <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reactions_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">has condemned</a> Russia for its actions in Ukraine, accusing it of breaking international law and violating Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a>. Many countries implemented <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War">economic sanctions</a> against Russia, Russian individuals, or companies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[21]</a></sup> especially after the 2022 invasion.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="RussiaUkraine relations">RussiaUkraine relations</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Historical_background_of_the_2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="Historical background of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">Historical background of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Soviet_context_and_Orange_Revolution">Post-Soviet context and Orange Revolution</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a></div>
<p>After the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> (USSR) in 1991, Ukraine and Russia maintained close ties. In 1994, Ukraine agreed to accede to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</a> as a non-nuclear-weapon state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[22]</a></sup> Former Soviet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_in_Ukraine" title="Nuclear weapons in Ukraine">nuclear weapons in Ukraine</a> were removed and dismantled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[23]</a></sup> In return, Russia, the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> (UK), and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> (US) agreed to uphold the territorial integrity and political independence of Ukraine through the <a href="/wiki/Budapest_Memorandum_on_Security_Assurances" title="Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances">Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[25]</a></sup> In 1999, Russia was one of the signatories of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charter_for_European_Security" title="Charter for European Security">Charter for European Security</a>, which "reaffirmed the inherent right of each and every participating State to be free to choose or change its security arrangements, including treaties of alliance, as they evolve."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[26]</a></sup> In the years after the dissolution of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR">USSR</a>, several former <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> countries joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, partly in response to regional security threats involving Russia such as the <a href="/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis" title="1993 Russian constitutional crisis">1993 Russian constitutional crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Abkhazia_(1992%E2%80%931993)" title="War in Abkhazia (19921993)">War in Abkhazia</a> (19921993) and the <a href="/wiki/First_Chechen_War" title="First Chechen War">First Chechen War</a> (19941996). Russian leaders described this expansion as a violation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_powers" title="Western powers">Western powers</a>' informal assurances that NATO would not expand eastward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiegrefe_2022_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wiegrefe_2022-32">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2004_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2004 Ukrainian presidential election">2004 Ukrainian presidential election</a> was controversial. During the election campaign, opposition candidate <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yushchenko" title="Viktor Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poisoning_of_Viktor_Yushchenko" title="Poisoning of Viktor Yushchenko">poisoned</a> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TCDD_dioxin" title="TCDD dioxin">TCDD dioxin</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[30]</a></sup> he later implicated Russian involvement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[31]</a></sup> In November, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> was declared the winner, despite allegations of vote-rigging by election observers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[32]</a></sup> During a two-month period which became known as the Orange Revolution, large peaceful protests successfully challenged the outcome. After the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a> annulled the initial result due to widespread <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">electoral fraud</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2004_Ukrainian_presidential_election_re-run" title="2004 Ukrainian presidential election re-run">a second round re-run</a> was held, bringing to power Yushchenko as president and <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> as prime minister, and leaving Yanukovych in opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[33]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a> is often grouped together with other early-21st century protest movements, particularly within the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Former_USSR" title="Former USSR">former USSR</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Colour_revolution" title="Colour revolution">colour revolutions</a>. According to <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Cordesman" title="Anthony Cordesman">Anthony Cordesman</a>, Russian military officers viewed such colour revolutions as an attempt by the US and European states to destabilise neighbouring countries and undermine Russia's national security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[34]</a></sup> Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> accused organisers of the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%932013_Russian_protests" title="20112013 Russian protests">20112013 Russian protests</a> of being former advisors to Yushchenko, and described the protests as an attempt to transfer the Orange Revolution to Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[35]</a></sup> Rallies in favour of Putin during this period were called "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-Orange_protest" title="Anti-Orange protest">anti-Orange protests</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/2008_Bucharest_summit" title="2008 Bucharest summit">2008 Bucharest summit</a>, Ukraine and <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> sought to join NATO. The response among NATO members was divided; Western European countries opposed offering <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Membership_Action_Plan" title="Membership Action Plan">Membership Action Plans</a> (MAP) in order to avoid antagonising Russia, while US President <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> pushed for their admission.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[37]</a></sup> NATO ultimately refused to offer Ukraine and Georgia MAPs, but also issued a statement agreeing that "these countries will become members of NATO". Putin voiced strong opposition to Georgia and Ukraine's NATO membership bids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[38]</a></sup> By January 2022, the possibility of Ukraine joining NATO remained remote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Euromaidan.2C_Revolution_of_Dignity.2C_and_pro-Russian_unrest"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Euromaidan,_Revolution_of_Dignity,_and_pro-Russian_unrest">Euromaidan, Revolution of Dignity, and pro-Russian unrest</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine</a></div>
<p>In 2009, Yanukovych announced his intent to again run for president in the <a href="/wiki/2010_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2010 Ukrainian presidential election">2010 Ukrainian presidential election</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[40]</a></sup> which he subsequently won.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[41]</a></sup> In November 2013, a wave of large, pro-<a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) protests erupted in response to Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU%E2%80%93Ukraine_Association_Agreement" title="EUUkraine Association Agreement">EUUkraine Association Agreement</a>, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">Eurasian Economic Union</a>. The Ukrainian parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the agreement with the EU,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[42]</a></sup> and Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following months of protests as part of the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> movement, on 21 February 2014 Yanukovych and the leaders of the parliamentary opposition signed a <a href="/wiki/Agreement_on_settlement_of_political_crisis_in_Ukraine" title="Agreement on settlement of political crisis in Ukraine">settlement agreement</a> that called for early elections. The following day, Yanukovych fled from the capital ahead of an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">impeachment vote</a> that stripped him of his powers as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-interfax1_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-interfax1-49">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aljz01_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Aljz01-50">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RadioFreeEurope_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-RadioFreeEurope-51">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-huffingtonpost1_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-huffingtonpost1-52">[47]</a></sup>  On 23 February, the parliament adopted a <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">bill</a> to repeal the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislation_on_languages_in_Ukraine" title="Legislation on languages in Ukraine">2012 law</a> which gave Russian language an official status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[48]</a></sup> The bill was not <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enactment_of_a_bill" title="Enactment of a bill">enacted</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[49]</a></sup> however, the proposal provoked negative reactions in the Russian-speaking regions of Ukraine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[50]</a></sup> intensified by Russian media saying that the ethnic Russian population was in imminent danger.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 27 February, an <a href="/wiki/First_Yatsenyuk_government" title="First Yatsenyuk government">interim government</a> was established and early presidential elections were scheduled. The following day, Yanukovych resurfaced in Russia and in a press conference declared that he remained the acting president of Ukraine, just as Russia was beginning its overt military campaign in Crimea. Leaders of Russian-speaking <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">eastern</a> regions of Ukraine declared continuing loyalty to Yanukovych,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aljz01_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-Aljz01-50">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup> causing the <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_bases_in_Crimea">Russian bases in Crimea</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Crimea" title="Political status of Crimea">Political status of Crimea</a></div>
<p>At the onset of the conflict, Russia had roughly 12,000 military personnel in the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Fleet" title="Black Sea Fleet">Black Sea Fleet</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup> in several locations in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crimean_peninsula" title="Crimean peninsula">Crimean peninsula</a> like Sevastopol, <a href="/wiki/Kacha,_Sevastopol" title="Kacha, Sevastopol">Kacha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hvardiiske,_Simferopol_Raion" title="Hvardiiske, Simferopol Raion">Hvardiiske, Simferopol Raion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarych" title="Sarych">Sarych</a>, and others. In 2005 a dispute broke out over control of the <a href="/wiki/Sarych" title="Sarych">Sarych</a> cape lighthouse near Yalta, and a number of other beacons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup> Russian presence was allowed by the <a href="/wiki/Partition_Treaty_on_the_Status_and_Conditions_of_the_Black_Sea_Fleet" title="Partition Treaty on the Status and Conditions of the Black Sea Fleet">basing and transit agreement</a> with Ukraine. Under the agreements the Russian military in Crimea was constrained to a maximum of 25,000 troops, required to respect the sovereignty of Ukraine, honor its legislation and to not interfere in the internal affairs of the country, and to show their "military identification cards" when crossing the international border. Operations beyond designated deployment sites were permitted only after coordination with the competent agencies of Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[55]</a></sup> Early in the conflict, the agreement's sizeable troop limit allowed Russia to significantly reinforce its military presence under the plausible guise of security concerns, deploy special forces and other required capabilities to conduct the operation in Crimea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-2"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the original treaty on the division of the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Fleet" title="Black Sea Fleet">Black Sea Fleet</a> signed in 1997, Russia was allowed to have its military bases in Crimea until 2017, after which it would evacuate all military units including its portion of the Black Sea Fleet out of the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Republic_of_Crimea" title="Autonomous Republic of Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a> and Sevastopol. A Russian construction project to re-home the fleet in <a href="/wiki/Novorossiysk" title="Novorossiysk">Novorossiysk</a> launched in 2005 and was expected to be fully completed by 2020; as of 2010, the project faced major budget cuts and construction delays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[56]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (April 2022)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> On 21 April 2010, former Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych signed a new deal known as the <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_Pact" title="Kharkiv Pact">Kharkiv Pact</a>, to resolve the <a href="/wiki/2009_Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_gas_dispute" title="2009 RussiaUkraine gas dispute">2009 RussiaUkraine gas dispute</a>; it extended the stay to 2042 with an option to renew, and in return obtained some discounts on gas delivered from Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kharkiv Pact was an update to a complex of several fundamental treaties signed in the 1990s between the prime ministers of both countries <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Chernomyrdin" title="Viktor Chernomyrdin">Viktor Chernomyrdin</a> (Russia) and <a href="/wiki/Pavlo_Lazarenko" title="Pavlo Lazarenko">Pavlo Lazarenko</a> (Ukraine), and presidents <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> (Russia) and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kuchma" title="Leonid Kuchma">Leonid Kuchma</a> (Ukraine).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[61]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (October 2021)">non-primary source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a>, whilst generally prohibiting the deployment of foreign bases on the country's soil, originally also had a transitional provision, which allowed the use of existing military bases on the territory of Ukraine for the temporary stationing of foreign military formations; this permitted Russian military to keep its basing in Crimea as an "existing military base". The constitutional provision on "[pre]-existing bases" was revoked in 2019, after Russia had already annexed Crimea and withdrawn from the basing treaties unilaterally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Declaration_of_military_operations">Declaration of military operations</span></h3>
<p>No formal declaration of war has been issued in the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War. When the Kremlin announced the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, it claimed to commence <a href="/wiki/On_conducting_a_special_military_operation" title="On conducting a special military operation">a "special military operation"</a>, side-stepping a formal declaration of war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[63]</a></sup> The statement was, however, regarded as a declaration of war by the Ukrainian government<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[64]</a></sup> and reported as such by many international news sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[66]</a></sup> While the Ukrainian parliament refers to Russia as a "terrorist state" in regards to its military actions in Ukraine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[67]</a></sup> it has not issued a formal declaration of war on its behalf.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Russian_annexation_of_Crimea_.282014.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_annexation_of_Crimea_(2014)">Russian annexation of Crimea (2014)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Timeline of the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Timeline of the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1552" data-file-width="2337" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG/220px-2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG/330px-2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG/440px-2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The blockade of military units of the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine" title="Armed Forces of Ukraine">Armed Forces of Ukraine</a> during the capture of Crimea by Russia in FebruaryMarch 2014</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG/220px-2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG/330px-2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG/440px-2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014-03-09_-_Perevalne_military_base_-_0203.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian troops blocking the Ukrainian military base in <a href="/wiki/Perevalne" title="Perevalne">Perevalne</a></div></div></div>
<p>On 20 February 2014, Russia began <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">an annexation of Crimea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CrimeanInvasion_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-CrimeanInvasion-75">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UkrainianPerspective_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-UkrainianPerspective-76">[71]</a></sup> On 22 and 23 February, Russian troops and <a href="/wiki/Spetsnaz" title="Spetsnaz">special forces</a> began moving into Crimea through <a href="/wiki/Novorossiysk" title="Novorossiysk">Novorossiysk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CrimeanInvasion_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-CrimeanInvasion-75">[70]</a></sup> On 27 February, <a href="/wiki/Little_green_men_(Russo-Ukrainian_War)" title="Little green men (Russo-Ukrainian War)">Russian forces without insignias</a> began their advance into the <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimean</a> Peninsula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yahoo_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-yahoo-77">[72]</a></sup> They took strategic positions and <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_the_Crimean_Parliament" title="Capture of the Crimean Parliament">captured the Crimean Parliament</a>, raising a Russian flag. Security checkpoints isolated the Crimean Peninsula from the rest of Ukraine and restricted movement within the territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the following days, Russian soldiers secured key airports and a communications center.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forceAuth_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-forceAuth-82">[77]</a></sup> Russian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian-Ukrainian_cyberwarfare" title="Russian-Ukrainian cyberwarfare">cyberattacks</a> shut down websites associated with the Ukrainian government, news media, and social media. Cyberattacks also enabled Russian access to the mobile phones of Ukrainian officials and members of parliament, further disrupting communications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jw_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-jw-83">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 March, the Russian legislature approved the use of armed forces, leading to an influx of Russian troops and military hardware into the peninsula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forceAuth_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-forceAuth-82">[77]</a></sup> In the following days, all remaining Ukrainian military bases and installations were surrounded and besieged, including the <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Southern_Naval_Base" title="Capture of Southern Naval Base">Southern Naval Base</a>. After Russia formally annexed the peninsula on 18 March, Ukrainian military bases and ships were stormed by Russian forces. On 24 March, Ukraine ordered troops to withdraw; by 30 March, all Ukrainian forces had left the peninsula.
</p><p>On 15 April, the Ukrainian parliament declared Crimea a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporarily_occupied_territories_of_Ukraine" title="Temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine">territory temporarily occupied by Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apr15_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-apr15-84">[79]</a></sup> After the annexation, the Russian government increased its military presence in the region and made nuclear threats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[80]</a></sup> Putin said that a Russian military task force would be established in Crimea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[81]</a></sup> In November, NATO stated that it believed Russia was deploying nuclear-capable weapons to Crimea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-87">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2014.E2.80.932015_war_in_Donbas"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="20142015_war_in_Donbas">20142015 war in Donbas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_war_in_Donbas" title="Timeline of the war in Donbas">Timeline of the war in Donbas</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Combatants_of_the_war_in_Donbas" title="Combatants of the war in Donbas">Combatants of the war in Donbas</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_equipment_used_by_Russian_separatist_forces_of_the_war_in_Donbas" title="List of equipment used by Russian separatist forces of the war in Donbas">List of equipment used by Russian separatist forces of the war in Donbas</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pro-Russia_unrest">Pro-Russia unrest</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine</a></div>
<p>The first protests across southern and eastern Ukraine were largely native expressions of discontent with the new Ukrainian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-de-88">[83]</a></sup> Russian involvement at this stage was limited to voicing support for the demonstrations. The emergence of separatists in Donetsk and Luhansk began with a small group of protesters, independent of Russian control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-de-88">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wil234_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-wil234-89">[84]</a></sup> Russia exploited this, however, launching a coordinated political and military campaign against Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-de-88">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karb2_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-karb2-90">[85]</a></sup> Putin gave legitimacy to the separatists when he described the Donbas as part of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Russia" title="New Russia">New Russia</a>" (<i>Novorossiya</i>), and expressed bewilderment as to how the region had ever become part of Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukrainian authorities cracked down on the pro-Russian protests and arrested local separatist leaders in early March. Those leaders were replaced by people with ties to the Russian security services and interests in Russian businesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de99_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-de99-92">[87]</a></sup> By April 2014, Russian citizens had taken control of the separatist movement, supported by volunteers and materiel from Russia, including <a href="/wiki/Chechens" title="Chechens">Chechen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> fighters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de2_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-de2-93">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jamestown-20140815_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-jamestown-20140815-94">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REUeuada_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-REUeuada-95">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[91]</a></sup> According to DPR  commander <a href="/wiki/Igor_Girkin" title="Igor Girkin">Igor Girkin</a>, without this support in April, the movement would have dissipated, as it had in Kharkiv and Odessa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wil2399_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-wil2399-97">[92]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2014_Donetsk_status_referendum" title="2014 Donetsk status referendum">disputed referendum</a> on the status of Donetsk Oblast was held on 11 May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referendum-rebels_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-referendum-rebels-98">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>These demonstrations were part of a wider group of concurrent pro-Russian protests across southern and eastern Ukraine. They escalated into an <a href="/wiki/War" title="War">armed conflict</a> between Russia-backed <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">separatist forces</a> of the self-declared <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">Donetsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">Luhansk</a> People's Republics (DPR and LPR respectively), and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ukraine" title="Government of Ukraine">Ukrainian government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[97]</a></sup> The SBU claimed that key rebel commanders, including Igor Strelkov and <a href="/wiki/Igor_Bezler" title="Igor Bezler">Igor Bezler</a>, were Russian agents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tg0x01_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-tg0x01-103">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tgox02_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-tgox02-104">[99]</a></sup> The prime minister of Donetsk People's Republic from May to August 2014 was a Russian citizen, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Borodai" title="Alexander Borodai">Alexander Borodai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REUeuada_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-REUeuada-95">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>After August 2014, all top positions in Donetsk and Luhansk were held by Ukrainian citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes0x01_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes0x01-105">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jamestown-20140815_94-1"><a href="#cite_note-jamestown-20140815-94">[89]</a></sup> Russian volunteers were reported to make up from 15% to 80% of the combatants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REUeuada_95-2"><a href="#cite_note-REUeuada-95">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[104]</a></sup> with many said to be former military personnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gruz200_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-gruz200-110">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NW296937_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-NW296937-111">[106]</a></sup> Recruitment for Donbas insurgents was openly conducted in Russian cities using private or <a href="/wiki/Military_commissariat" title="Military commissariat">voyenkomat</a> facilities, as was confirmed by Russian media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gruz200_110-1"><a href="#cite_note-gruz200-110">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Economic and material circumstances in Donbas generated neither necessary nor sufficient conditions for a locally rooted, internally driven armed conflict. The Kremlin's military intervention was essential for hostilities to begin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="April.E2.80.93July_2014"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="AprilJuly_2014">AprilJuly 2014</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RU_and_UA_forces,_2014.02_(February)_-_EN_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1260" data-file-width="1785" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg/220px-RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg/330px-RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg/440px-RU_and_UA_forces%2C_2014.02_%28February%29_-_EN_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RU_and_UA_forces,_2014.02_(February)_-_EN_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Russian military buildup along Ukraine's eastern border in FebruaryMarch 2014</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg/220px-2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg/330px-2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg/440px-2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014-05-11._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BC_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/2014_Donbas_status_referendums" title="2014 Donbas status referendums">Donbas status referendums</a> in May 2014 were not officially recognised by the <a href="/wiki/First_Yatsenyuk_government" title="First Yatsenyuk government">Ukrainian government</a> or any UN member state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referendum-rebels_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-referendum-rebels-98">[93]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In late March, Russia continued to gather forces near the Ukrainian eastern border, reaching 3040,000 troops by April.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buildup2014_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buildup2014-114">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-3"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup> The deployment was used to threaten escalation and disrupt Ukraine's response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-4"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup> This threat forced Ukraine to divert forces to its borders instead of the conflict zone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014Lessons_56-5"><a href="#cite_note-2014Lessons-56">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April, <a href="/wiki/War" title="War">armed conflict</a> began in eastern Ukraine between Russian-backed separatist forces and Ukraine. The separatists declared the People's Republics of Donetsk and Luhansk. From 6 April, militants occupied government buildings in many cities and took control of border crossings to Russia, transport hubs, a broadcasting center, and other strategic infrastructure. Faced with continued expansion of separatist territorial control, on 15 April the interim Ukrainian government launched an "<a href="/wiki/Anti-terrorist_Operation_Zone" title="Anti-terrorist Operation Zone">Anti-Terrorist Operation</a>" (ATO), however, Ukrainian forces were poorly prepared and ill-positioned and the operation quickly stalled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrregularArmy_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-IrregularArmy-115">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of April, Ukraine announced it had lost control of the provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk. It claimed to be on "full combat alert" against a possible Russian invasion and reinstated conscription to its armed forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conscription_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-conscription-116">[111]</a></sup> Through May, the Ukrainian campaign focused on containing the separatists by securing key positions around the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-Terrorist_Operation_Zone_(Ukraine)" title="Anti-Terrorist Operation Zone (Ukraine)">ATO zone</a> to position the military for a decisive offensive once Ukraine's national mobilization had completed.
</p><p>As conflict between the separatists and the Ukrainian government escalated in May, Russia began to employ a "<a href="/wiki/Hybrid_warfare" title="Hybrid warfare">hybrid</a> approach", combining disinformation tactics, irregular fighters, regular Russian troops, and conventional military support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de3_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-de3-117">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fedorov_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fedorov-118">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karber2_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-karber2-119">[114]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Donetsk_Airport" title="First Battle of Donetsk Airport">First Battle of Donetsk Airport</a> followed the <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2014 Ukrainian presidential election">Ukrainian presidential elections</a>. It marked a turning point in conflict; it was the first battle between the separatists and the Ukrainian government that involved large numbers of Russian "volunteers".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de98_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-de98-120">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LoshkariovSushentsov2016_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-LoshkariovSushentsov2016-121">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 15">:15</span></sup> According to Ukraine, at the height of the conflict in the summer of 2014, Russian paramilitaries made up between 15% to 80% of the combatants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REUeuada_95-3"><a href="#cite_note-REUeuada-95">[90]</a></sup> From June Russia trickled in arms, armor, and munitions.
</p><p>By the end of July, Ukrainian forces were pushing into cities, to cut off supply routes between the two, isolating Donetsk and attempting to <a href="/wiki/Fights_on_the_Ukrainian%E2%80%93Russian_border_(2014)" title="Fights on the UkrainianRussian border (2014)">restore control of the Russo-Ukrainian border</a>. By 28 July, the strategic heights of <a href="/wiki/Savur-Mohyla" title="Savur-Mohyla">Savur-Mohyla</a> were under Ukrainian control, along with the town of <a href="/wiki/Debaltseve" title="Debaltseve">Debaltseve</a>, an important railroad hub.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IFheights_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-IFheights-122">[117]</a></sup> These operational successes of Ukrainian forces threatened the existence of the DPR and LPR statelets, prompting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_cross-border_artillery_shelling_of_Ukraine_(2014)" title="Russian cross-border artillery shelling of Ukraine (2014)">Russian cross-border shelling</a> targeted against Ukrainian troops on their own soil, from mid-July onwards.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>American and Ukrainian officials said they had evidence of Russian interference in Ukraine, including <a href="/wiki/Signals_intelligence" title="Signals intelligence">intercepted</a> communications between Russian officials and Donbas insurgents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tdb0x01_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-tdb0x01-123">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ukrainian media described the militants as similar to those who occupied Crimea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kpslov_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-kpslov-125">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pravdagreen_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-pravdagreen-126">[121]</a></sup> The former deputy <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_General_Staff_(Ukraine)" title="Chief of the General Staff (Ukraine)">Chief of the General Staff</a> of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, Admiral Ihor Kabanenko, said that the militants were Russian military reconnaissance and <a href="/wiki/2014_Russian_sabotage_activities_in_Ukraine" title="2014 Russian sabotage activities in Ukraine">sabotage units</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[122]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arsen_Avakov" title="Arsen Avakov">Arsen Avakov</a> stated that the militants in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krasnyi_Lyman" title="Krasnyi Lyman">Krasnyi Lyman</a> used Russian-made <a href="/wiki/AK-101" title="AK-101">AK-100 series</a> assault rifles fitted with grenade launchers, and that such weapons were issued only in the Russian Federation. "The Government of Ukraine is considering the facts of today as a manifestation of external aggression by Russia," said Avakov.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pravdaapr12_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-pravdaapr12-128">[123]</a></sup> Militants in <a href="/wiki/Sloviansk" title="Sloviansk">Sloviansk</a> arrived in military lorries without license plates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[124]</a></sup> A reporter from Russia's <i><a href="/wiki/Novaya_Gazeta" title="Novaya Gazeta">Novaya Gazeta</a></i>, after visiting separatist artillery positions in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avdeyevka" title="Avdeyevka">Avdeyevka</a>, wrote that in his opinion "it's impossible that the cannons are handled by volunteers" as they require training and experience, including observers and adjustment experts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="August_2014_Russian_invasion">August 2014 Russian invasion</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ilovaisk" title="Battle of Ilovaisk">Battle of Ilovaisk</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:War_in_donbass.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="570" decoding="async" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/War_in_donbass.svg/220px-War_in_donbass.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/War_in_donbass.svg/330px-War_in_donbass.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/War_in_donbass.svg/440px-War_in_donbass.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:War_in_donbass.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>JuneAugust 2014 progression map</div></div></div>
<p>After a series of military defeats and setbacks for the separatists, who united under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_Federal_State_of_Novorossiya" title="Flag of the Federal State of Novorossiya">banner</a> of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_State_of_Novorossiya" title="Federal State of Novorossiya">Novorossiya</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[127]</a></sup> Russia dispatched what it called a "humanitarian convoy" of trucks across the border in mid-August 2014. Ukraine called the move a "direct invasion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[128]</a></sup> Ukraine's National Security and Defence Council reported that convoys were arriving almost daily in November (up to 9 convoys on 30 November) and that their contents were mainly arms and ammunition. Strelkov claimed that in early August, Russian servicemen, supposedly on "vacation" from the army, began to arrive in Donbas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>By August 2014, the Ukrainian "Anti-Terrorist Operation" shrank the territory under pro-Russian control, and approached the border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de4_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-de4-135">[130]</a></sup> Igor Girkin urged Russian military intervention, and said that the combat inexperience of his irregular forces, along with recruitment difficulties amongst the local population, had caused the setbacks. He stated, "Losing this war on the territory that President Vladimir Putin personally named New Russia would threaten the Kremlin's power and, personally, the power of the president".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Beast_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Beast-136">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>In response to the deteriorating situation, Russia abandoned its hybrid approach, and began a conventional invasion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-de4_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-de4-135">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[132]</a></sup> on 25 August 2014 when SBU captured a group of Russian paratroopers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[133]</a></sup> SBU released names and photographs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[134]</a></sup> On the following day, the Russian Defence Ministry said these soldiers had crossed the border "by accident".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC26AUGY2_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC26AUGY2-140">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[137]</a></sup> According to Nikolai Mitrokhin's estimates, by mid-August 2014 during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ilovaisk" title="Battle of Ilovaisk">Battle of Ilovaisk</a>, between 20,000 and 25,000 troops were fighting in the Donbas on the separatist side, and only 40-45% were "locals".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wil2_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-wil2-143">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 24 August 2014, <a href="/wiki/Amvrosiivka" title="Amvrosiivka">Amvrosiivka</a> was occupied by Russian paratroopers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup> supported by 250 armoured vehicles and artillery pieces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[140]</a></sup> The same day, Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> referred to the operation as Ukraine's "Patriotic War of 2014" and a war against external aggression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[142]</a></sup> Ten Russian paratroopers of the <a href="/wiki/331st_Guards_Airborne_Regiment" title="331st Guards Airborne Regiment">331st Guards Airborne Regiment</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_unit" title="Military unit">military unit</a> 71211 from <a href="/wiki/Kostroma" title="Kostroma">Kostroma</a>, were captured in <a href="/wiki/Dzerkalne" title="Dzerkalne">Dzerkalne</a> (near Amvrosiivka) that day, 20 kilometres (12 mi) from the border,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCcrtoi_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCcrtoi-148">[143]</a></sup> after their armoured vehicles were hit by Ukrainian artillery. On 25 August, SBU reported the capture of paratroopers who claimed they'd crossed the Ukrainian border by accident on 23 August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[144]</a></sup> SBU also released their photos and names.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 25 August, a column of Russian military vehicles was reported to have crossed into Ukraine near <a href="/wiki/Novoazovsk" title="Novoazovsk">Novoazovsk</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azov_sea" title="Azov sea">Azov sea</a> coast. It appeared headed towards Ukrainian-held <a href="/wiki/Mariupol" title="Mariupol">Mariupol</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Russian_Column_enters_southeast_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Russian_Column_enters_southeast-151">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Column_from_Russia_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-Column_from_Russia-152">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npr_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-npr-153">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNBCx1_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNBCx1-154">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[150]</a></sup> in an area that had not seen pro-Russian presence for weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[151]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bellingcat" title="Bellingcat">Bellingcat</a> investigation revealed some details of this operation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[152]</a></sup> Russian forces captured <a href="/wiki/Novoazovsk" title="Novoazovsk">Novoazovsk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WPTowns_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-WPTowns-158">[153]</a></sup> and Russian soldiers began deporting Ukrainians who did not have an address registered within the town.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiadomosci.gazeta.pl_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-wiadomosci.gazeta.pl-159">[154]</a></sup> Pro-Ukrainian anti-war protests took place in <a href="/wiki/Mariupol" title="Mariupol">Mariupol</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiadomosci.gazeta.pl_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-wiadomosci.gazeta.pl-159">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[155]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a> called an emergency meeting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usatoday0x01_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-usatoday0x01-161">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1365" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG/220px-2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG/330px-2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG/440px-2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014-08-26._%C2%AB%D0%A1%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%C2%BB_%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D1%8F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BD%D1%83_035.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Residents of <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> with <a href="/wiki/Sich_Battalion" title="Sich Battalion">Sich Battalion</a> volunteers on 26 August 2014</div></div></div>
