<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pskov" title="Pskov">Pskov</a>-based <a href="/wiki/76th_Guards_Air_Assault_Division" title="76th Guards Air Assault Division">76th Guards Air Assault Division</a> allegedly entered Ukrainian territory in August and engaged in a skirmish near <a href="/wiki/Luhansk" title="Luhansk">Luhansk</a>, suffering 80 dead. The Ukrainian Defence Ministry said that they had seized two of the unit's armoured vehicles near Luhansk, and reported destroying another three tanks and two armoured vehicles in other regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyp01xbb_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyp01xbb-163">[158]</a></sup> The Russian government denied the skirmish took place,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyp01xbb_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-nyp01xbb-163">[158]</a></sup> but on 18 August, the 76th was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Suvorov" title="Order of Suvorov">Order of Suvorov</a>, one of Russia's highest awards, by Russian minister of defence <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sergey_Shoigu" title="Sergey Shoigu">Sergey Shoigu</a> for the "successful completion of military missions" and "courage and heroism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyp01xbb_163-2"><a href="#cite_note-nyp01xbb-163">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian media highlighted that the medal is awarded exclusively for combat operations and reported that soldiers from this division had died in Ukraine just days before, but their burials were conducted in secret.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gazeta_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-gazeta-166">[161]</a></sup> Some Russian media, such as <i>Pskovskaya Guberniya</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup> reported that Russian paratroopers might have been killed in Ukraine. Journalists traveled to Pskov, the reported burial site, to investigate. Multiple reporters said they had been attacked or threatened there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_Pskov_reporters_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_Pskov_reporters-168">[163]</a></sup> <i>Pskovskaya Guberniya</i> revealed transcripts of phone conversations between Russian soldiers undergoing treatment in a Pskov hospital for wounds received in Ukraine. The soldiers claimed that they had been sent to the war, after their officers told them that they were going on "an exercise".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Valentina_Matviyenko" title="Valentina Matviyenko">speaker of Russia's upper house of parliament</a> and Russian state television channels acknowledged that Russian soldiers entered Ukraine, but referred to them as "volunteers".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-funerals_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-funerals-171">[166]</a></sup> A reporter for <i><a href="/wiki/Novaya_Gazeta" title="Novaya Gazeta">Novaya Gazeta</a></i>, an opposition newspaper in Russia, stated that the Russian military leadership paid soldiers to resign their commissions and fight in Ukraine in the early summer of 2014, and then began ordering soldiers into Ukraine. This reporter mentioned knowledge of at least one case when soldiers who refused were threatened with prosecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[167]</a></sup> Russian opposition MP <a href="/wiki/Lev_Shlosberg" title="Lev Shlosberg">Lev Shlosberg</a> made similar statements, although he said combatants from his country are "regular Russian troops", disguised as units of the DPR and LPR.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ShlosbergSoldiers_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-ShlosbergSoldiers-173">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early September 2014, Russian state-owned television channels reported on the funerals of Russian soldiers who had died in Ukraine, but described them as "volunteers" fighting for the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_world_(concept)" title="Russian world (concept)">Russian world</a>". <a href="/wiki/Valentina_Matviyenko" title="Valentina Matviyenko">Valentina Matviyenko</a>, a top <a href="/wiki/United_Russia" title="United Russia">United Russia</a> politician, also praised "volunteers" fighting in "our fraternal nation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-funerals_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-funerals-171">[166]</a></sup> Russian state television for the first time showed the funeral of a soldier killed fighting in Ukraine. State-controlled TV station Channel One showed the burial of paratrooper Anatoly Travkin in the central Russian city of <a href="/wiki/Kostroma" title="Kostroma">Kostroma</a>. The broadcaster said Travkin had not told his wife or commanders about his decision to fight alongside pro-Russia rebels battling government forces. "Officially he just went on leave", the news reader said.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mariupol_offensive_and_first_Minsk_ceasefire">Mariupol offensive and first Minsk ceasefire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Offensive_on_Mariupol_(September_2014)" title="Offensive on Mariupol (September 2014)">Offensive on Mariupol (September 2014)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minsk_agreements" title="Minsk agreements">Minsk agreements</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Minsk_Protocol.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="527" data-file-width="480" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Minsk_Protocol.svg/170px-Minsk_Protocol.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Minsk_Protocol.svg/255px-Minsk_Protocol.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Minsk_Protocol.svg/340px-Minsk_Protocol.svg.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Minsk_Protocol.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of the line of control and buffer zone established by the Minsk Protocol on 5 September 2014</div></div></div>
<p>On 3 September 2014, <a href="/wiki/Sky_News" title="Sky News">Sky News</a> filmed groups of troops near <a href="/wiki/Novoazovsk" title="Novoazovsk">Novoazovsk</a> wearing combat gear typical for Russian units and traveling in new military vehicles without license plates and other markings. Specialists consulted by the journalists identified parts of the equipment (uniform, rifles) as matching those used by Russian forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also on, 3 September, Poroshenko said he and Putin had reached a "permanent ceasefire" agreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-interfax_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-interfax-176">[171]</a></sup> Russia denied this, denying that it was a party to the conflict, adding that "they only discussed how to settle the conflict".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kyivpost_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-kyivpost-178">[173]</a></sup> Poroshenko then recanted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-179">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mick Krever wrote on the <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> blog that on 5 September Russia's Permanent OSCE Representative <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Kelin" title="Andrey Kelin">Andrey Kelin</a>, said that it was natural that pro-Russian separatists "are going to liberate" <a href="/wiki/Mariupol" title="Mariupol">Mariupol</a>. Ukrainian forces stated that Russian intelligence groups had been spotted in the area. Kelin said 'there might be volunteers over there.'<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup> On 4 September 2014, a NATO officer said that several thousand regular Russian forces operating in Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 5 September 2014, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minsk_Protocol" title="Minsk Protocol">Minsk Protocol</a> ceasefire agreement drew a line of demarcation between Ukraine and separatist-controlled portions of Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="November_2014_escalation">November 2014 escalation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2014_Russian_cross-border_shelling_of_Ukraine" title="2014 Russian cross-border shelling of Ukraine">2014 Russian cross-border shelling of Ukraine</a></div>
<p>On 7 and 12 November, NATO officials reconfirmed the Russian presence, citing 32 tanks, 16 <a href="/wiki/Howitzer" title="Howitzer">howitzer</a> cannons and 30 trucks of troops entering the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[178]</a></sup> US general <a href="/wiki/Philip_M._Breedlove" title="Philip M. Breedlove">Philip M. Breedlove</a> said "Russian tanks, Russian artillery, Russian air defence systems and Russian combat troops" had been sighted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-87">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[179]</a></sup> Journalist Menahem Kahana took a picture showing a 1RL232 "Leopard" battlefield surveillance radar system in Torez, east of Donetsk; and Dutch freelance journalist Stefan Huijboom took pictures that showed the 1RL232 traveling with the 1RL239 "Lynx" radar system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>OSCE monitors further observed vehicles apparently used to transport soldiers' dead bodies crossing the border  in one case a vehicle marked with <a href="/wiki/Cargo_200_(code_name)" title="Cargo 200 (code name)">Russia's military code for soldiers killed in action</a> crossed into Ukraine on 11 November 2014, and later returned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc.co.uk_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc.co.uk-186">[181]</a></sup> On 23 January 2015 the Committee of Soldiers' Mothers warned about conscripts sent to east Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[182]</a></sup> NATO said it had seen an increase in Russian tanks, artillery pieces and other heavy military equipment in Ukraine and renewed its call for Moscow to withdraw its forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uatoday.tv_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-uatoday.tv-188">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>The centre for Eurasian Strategic Intelligence estimated that over 30 Russian military units were taking part in the conflict. In total, over 8,000 soldiers fought there at different moments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[184]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Council_on_Global_Affairs" title="Chicago Council on Global Affairs">Chicago Council on Global Affairs</a> stated that Russian separatists enjoyed technical advantages over the Ukrainian army since the large inflow of advanced military systems in mid-2014: effective anti-aircraft weapons ("<a href="/wiki/Buk_missile_system" title="Buk missile system">Buk</a>", MANPADS) suppressed Ukrainian air strikes, Russian drones provided intelligence, and Russian secure communications system disrupted Ukrainian communications intelligence. The Russian side employed <a href="/wiki/Electronic_warfare" title="Electronic warfare">electronic warfare</a> systems that Ukraine lacked. Similar conclusions about the technical advantage of the Russian separatists were voiced by the Conflict Studies Research Centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous reports of Russian troops and warfare on Ukrainian territory were raised in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> meetings. In 12 November meeting, the United Kingdom's representative accused Russia of intentionally constraining <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a> observation missions' capabilities, pointing out that the observers were allowed to monitor only two kilometers of border, and drones deployed to extend their capabilities were jammed or shot down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2015_and_ceasefire">2015 and ceasefire</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg/220px-2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg/330px-2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg/440px-2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2015-05-07._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_175.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pro-Russian rebels in <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> in May 2015. Ukraine declared the Russia-backed <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">separatist</a> republics from eastern Ukraine to be <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorist</a> organizations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[187]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In January, <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luhansk" title="Luhansk">Luhansk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariupol" title="Mariupol">Mariupol</a> represented the three battle fronts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> described a dangerous escalation on 21 January amid reports of more than 2,000 additional Russian troops, 200 tanks and armed personnel carriers crossing the border. He abbreviated his visit to the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> because of his concerns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 28 January, on the outskirts of <a href="/wiki/Khartsyzk" title="Khartsyzk">Khartsyzk</a>, the OSCE observed "a column of five <a href="/wiki/T-72" title="T-72">T-72</a> tanks facing east, and immediately after, another four T-72 tanks moving east, accompanied by four unmarked URAL type military trucks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> Residential areas in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Offensive_on_Mariupol_(January_2015)" title="Offensive on Mariupol (January 2015)">Mariupol</a> were shelled."'<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uatoday.tv_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-uatoday.tv-188">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>A new package of measures to end the conflict, known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minsk_II" title="Minsk II">Minsk II</a>, was agreed on 15 February 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[192]</a></sup> On 18 February, Ukrainian forces <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Debaltseve" title="Battle of Debaltseve">withdrew from Debatlseve</a>, in the last major battle of the Donbas war. In September 2015 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Office" title="United Nations Human Rights Office">United Nations Human Rights Office</a> estimated that 8000 casualties had resulted from the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[193]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2015.E2.80.932022"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="20152022">20152022</span></h3><p>
US and international officials continued to report the active presence of Russian military in eastern Ukraine, including in the Debaltseve area".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[194]</a></sup> In January, Ukrainian troops struggled to counter artillery fire, due to Russian-supplied drones and <a href="/wiki/Radar_jamming_and_deception" title="Radar jamming and deception">jamming</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[196]</a></sup> Russian separatists forces were estimated to number around 36,000 troops (compared to 34,000 Ukrainian), of whom 8,50010,000 were Russian soldiers. Additionally, around 1,000 <a href="/wiki/GRU" title="GRU">GRU</a> troops were operating in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup> Another estimate held that Ukrainian forces outnumbered Russian forces 40,000 to 20,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[198]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg/220px-2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg/330px-2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg/440px-2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2015-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_067.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Casualties of the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbas_(2014%E2%80%932022)" title="War in Donbas (20142022)">war in Donbas</a></div></div></div>
<p>In February <i><a href="/wiki/Novaya_Gazeta" title="Novaya Gazeta">Novaya Gazeta</a></i> obtained documents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Novaya_predstavlyaetsya2_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-Novaya_predstavlyaetsya2-204">[199]</a></sup> allegedly written by <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Malofeev" title="Konstantin Malofeev">Konstantin Malofayev</a> and others, that provided the Russian government with a strategy in the event of Yanukovych's removal and the break-up of Ukraine, then considered likely. The documents outlined plans for annexing Crimea and the eastern portions of the country, closely matching actual events. The documents described plans for a public relations campaign to justify Russian actions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_financing_of_militias_and_Glazyev_tapes">Russian financing of militias and Glazyev tapes</span></h4>
<p>In August 2016, SBU published telephone intercepts from 2014 of <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Glazyev" title="Sergey Glazyev">Sergey Glazyev</a> (Russian presidential adviser), <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Zatulin" title="Konstantin Zatulin">Konstantin Zatulin</a>, and other people in which they discussed covert funding of pro-Russian activists in Eastern Ukraine, the occupation of administration buildings and other actions that triggered the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>As early as February 2014, Glazyev gave direct instructions to various pro-Russian parties on how to take over local administration offices, what to do afterwards, how to formulate demands, and promised support from Russia, including "sending our guys".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[206]</a></sup> In later recorded calls he identified other tactics, well before the invasion took shape.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_troop_activities">Russian troop activities</span></h4>
<p>One report stated that 42,000 regular Russian combat troops were involved in the fighting, with a peak strength of 10,000 in December 2014. The direct involvement of the Russian troops on Ukrainian territory began in August 2014, when Ukrainian forces seemed poised for victory, describin regular Donetsk and Luhansk rebel formations as "cannon fodder".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42k_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-42k-212">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RUSI2015_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-RUSI2015-213">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cases of killed and wounded Russian soldiers were discussed in local Russian media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian20150119_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian20150119-214">[209]</a></sup> Recruiting for Donbas was performed openly via veteran and paramilitary organisations. Vladimir Yefimov, leader of one such organisation, explained how the process worked in the <a href="/wiki/Ural_(region)" title="Ural (region)">Ural</a> area. The organisation recruited mostly army veterans, but also policemen, firefighters etc. with military experience. The cost of equipping one volunteer was estimated at around 350,000 <a href="/wiki/Russian_ruble" title="Russian ruble">rubles</a> (around $6500) plus salary of 60,000 to 240,000 rubles per month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RuamlKP_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-RuamlKP-215">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>The volunteers were issued a document claiming that their participation was limited to "offering humanitarian help" to avoid Russian <a href="/wiki/Mercenary" title="Mercenary">mercenary</a> laws. Russia's anti-mercenary legislation defined a mercenary as someone who "takes part [in fighting] with aims counter to the interests of the Russian Federation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RuamlKP_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-RuamlKP-215">[210]</a></sup> The recruits received weapons only after arriving in the conflict zone. Often, Russian troops traveled disguised as Red Cross personnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NW296937_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-NW296937-111">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[213]</a></sup> Igor Trunov, head of the Russian Red Cross in Moscow, condemned these convoys, saying they complicated humanitarian aid delivery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia reinforced its military presence on the eastern border and near <a href="/wiki/Belgorod" title="Belgorod">Belgorod</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[215]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Vuhlehirsk" title="Vuhlehirsk">Vuhlehirsk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[216]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia refused to allow <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OSCE" title="OSCE">OSCE</a> to expand its mission beyond two border crossings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DW150624_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-DW150624-222">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2020 analysis of publicly available Russian railway traffic data (<i>gdevagon.ru</i>) indicated that in January 2015, a period of especially heavy fighting, thousands of tons of cargo declared "high explosives" were sent by railway into <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Uspenskaya" title="Uspenskaya">Uspenskaya</a>, a small train station on a line crossing from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rostovskaya_oblast%27" title="Rostovskaya oblast'">Rostovskaya oblast'</a> (Russia) into separatist Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="August_2016_escalation">August 2016 escalation</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg/220px-2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg/330px-2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg/440px-2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2016-05-09._%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_043.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian-backed separatists in May 2016</div></div></div>
<p>On 8 August 2016, Ukraine reported that Russia had increased its military presence along the Crimea demarcation line. Border crossings were closed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[219]</a></sup> On 10 August, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Security_Service" title="Federal Security Service">FSB</a> claimed it had prevented "Ukrainian terrorist attacks" and that two servicemen were killed in clashes in <a href="/wiki/Armiansk" title="Armiansk">Armiansk (Crimea)</a>, adding that "several" Ukrainian and Russian citizens were detained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[222]</a></sup> Russian media reported that one of the killed soldiers was a <a href="/wiki/GRU" title="GRU">GRU</a> commander, later buried in <a href="/wiki/Simferopol" title="Simferopol">Simferopol</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ukrainian government denied the incident.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[225]</a></sup> Parallel to the incident on 9 August, a Ukrainian official claimed that Russian soldiers had deserted but had not entered into Ukraine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[226]</a></sup> and that skirmishes broke out between Russian intelligence officers and border guards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[227]</a></sup> Putin accused Ukraine of turning to the "practice of terror".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[228]</a></sup> The U.S. denied Russia's claims, with its ambassador <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_R._Pyatt" title="Geoffrey R. Pyatt">Geoffrey R. Pyatt</a> rejecting Russian allegations of a "Crimea incursion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia then engaged in a rapid military build-up in Crimea,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016August_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-2016August-235">[230]</a></sup> followed by drills and military movement near the border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016August_235-1"><a href="#cite_note-2016August-235">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[231]</a></sup> Poroshenko warned that Russia was preparing for a full-scale invasion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2018_Kerch_Strait_incident">2018 Kerch Strait incident</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kerch_Strait_incident" title="Kerch Strait incident">Kerch Strait incident</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Ukraine" title="Martial law in Ukraine">Martial law in Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Black_Sea_incidents_involving_Russia_and_Ukraine" title="List of Black Sea incidents involving Russia and Ukraine">List of Black Sea incidents involving Russia and Ukraine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kerch_Strait_incident.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="824" data-file-width="1206" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Kerch_Strait_incident.png/220px-Kerch_Strait_incident.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Kerch_Strait_incident.png/330px-Kerch_Strait_incident.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Kerch_Strait_incident.png/440px-Kerch_Strait_incident.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kerch_Strait_incident.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Kerch Strait incident over the passage between the Black and Azov seas</div></div></div>
<p>Russia gained de facto control of the <a href="/wiki/Kerch_Strait" title="Kerch Strait">Kerch Strait</a> in 2014. In 2017, Ukraine appealed to a court of arbitration over the use of the strait. By 2018 Russia had built a bridge over the strait, limiting the size of ships that could pass through, imposed new regulations, and repeatedly detained Ukrainian vessels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[234]</a></sup> On 25 November 2018, three Ukrainian boats traveling from Odessa to Mariupol were seized by Russian warships; 24 Ukrainian sailors were detained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[236]</a></sup> A day later on 26 November 2018, the Ukrainian parliament overwhelmingly backed the imposition of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">martial law</a> along Ukraine's coastal regions and those bordering Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2019.E2.80.932020"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="20192020">20192020</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_war_in_Donbas_(2019)" title="Timeline of the war in Donbas (2019)">Timeline of the war in Donbas (2019)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_war_in_Donbas_(2020)" title="Timeline of the war in Donbas (2020)">Timeline of the war in Donbas (2020)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Putin,_Macron,_Merkel,_Zelensky_(2019-12-10)_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg/220px-Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg/330px-Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg/440px-Putin%2C_Macron%2C_Merkel%2C_Zelensky_%282019-12-10%29_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Putin,_Macron,_Merkel,_Zelensky_(2019-12-10)_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>From left, Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>, French President <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a>, German Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> and Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> in Paris, France, December 2019</div></div></div>
<p>More than 110 Ukrainian soldiers were killed in the conflict in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-radiofree_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-radiofree-243">[238]</a></sup> In May 2019, newly elected Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> took office promising to end the war in Donbas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-radiofree_243-1"><a href="#cite_note-radiofree-243">[238]</a></sup> In December 2019, Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists began swapping <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war" title="Prisoners of war">prisoners of war</a>. Around 200 prisoners were exchanged on 29 December 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[242]</a></sup> According to Ukrainian authorities, 50 Ukrainian soldiers were killed in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[243]</a></sup> Since 2019, Russia has issued over 650,000 <a href="/wiki/Internal_passport_of_Russia" title="Internal passport of Russia">internal Russian passports</a> to Ukrainians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[245]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2021.E2.80.932022_Russian_military_buildup"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="20212022_Russian_military_buildup">20212022 Russian military buildup</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prelude_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Prelude to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Prelude to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_war_in_Donbas_(2021)" title="Timeline of the war in Donbas (2021)">Timeline of the war in Donbas (2021)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_war_in_Donbas_(2022)" title="Timeline of the war in Donbas (2022)">Timeline of the war in Donbas (2022)</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rise_in_tensions">Rise in tensions</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2nd_Battalion,_503rd_Infantry_Regiment,_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base,_Italy,_Feb._24,_2022.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1568" data-file-width="2352" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg/220px-2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg/330px-2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg/440px-2nd_Battalion%2C_503rd_Infantry_Regiment%2C_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base%2C_Italy%2C_Feb._24%2C_2022.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2nd_Battalion,_503rd_Infantry_Regiment,_173rd_Airborne_Brigade_depart_Aviano_Air_Base,_Italy,_Feb._24,_2022.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>US paratroopers of <a href="/wiki/2nd_Battalion,_503rd_Infantry_Regiment" title="2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment">2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry Regiment</a> depart Italy's <a href="/wiki/Aviano_Air_Base" title="Aviano Air Base">Aviano Air Base</a> for Latvia, 23 February 2022. Thousands of US troops were deployed to Eastern Europe amid Russia's military build-up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[246]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>From March to April 2021, Russia commenced a major military build-up near the border, followed by a second build-up between October 2021 to February 2022 in Russia and Belarus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zsymbol_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zsymbol-252">[247]</a></sup> Throughout, the Russian government repeatedly denied it had plans to attack Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-denials_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-denials-253">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early December 2021, following Russian denials, the US released intelligence of Russian invasion plans, including satellite photographs showing Russian troops and equipment near the border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[250]</a></sup> The intelligence reported a Russian list of key sites and individuals to be killed or neutralized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diditmatter_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-diditmatter-256">[251]</a></sup> The US release multiple reports that accurately predicted the invasion plans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diditmatter_256-1"><a href="#cite_note-diditmatter-256">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_accusations_and_demands">Russian accusations and demands</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_2021%E2%80%932022_Russo-Ukrainian_crisis" title="Disinformation in the 20212022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis">Disinformation in the 20212022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_irredentism" title="Russian irredentism">Russian irredentism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="RussiaNATO relations">RussiaNATO relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="UkraineNATO relations">UkraineNATO relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1250" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg/220px-Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg/330px-Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg/440px-Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Olga_Stefanishyna_held_press_conference_along_with_NATO_SG_Stoltenberg_about_possible_Russia_invasion.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ukrainian deputy prime minister <a href="/wiki/Olha_Stefanishyna" title="Olha Stefanishyna">Olha Stefanishyna</a> with NATO secretary-general <a href="/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg" title="Jens Stoltenberg">Jens Stoltenberg</a> at a conference on 10 January 2022 regarding a potential Russian invasion</div></div></div>
<p>In the months preceding the invasion, Russian officials accused Ukraine of inciting tensions, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russophobia" title="Russophobia">Russophobia</a>, and repressing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_speakers_in_Ukraine" title="Russian speakers in Ukraine">Russian speakers</a>. They made multiple security demands of Ukraine, NATO, and other EU countries. On 9 December 2021 Putin said that "Russophobia is a first step towards <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[253]</a></sup> Putin's claims were dismissed by the international community,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-animating_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-animating-259">[254]</a></sup> and Russian claims of genocide were rejected as baseless.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a 21 February speech,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[258]</a></sup> Putin questioned the legitimacy of the Ukrainian state, repeating an inaccurate claim that "Ukraine never had a tradition of genuine statehood".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[259]</a></sup> He incorrectly stated that <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a> had created Ukraine, by carving a separate Soviet Republic out of what Putin said was Russian land, that <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> extended Ukrainian territory with lands from other eastern European countries following the Second World War, and that <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> took <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a> away from Russia for some reason and gave it to Ukraine in 1954.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putin_Ukraine_statehood_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-Putin_Ukraine_statehood-25">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>Putin falsely claimed that Ukrainian society and government were dominated by <a href="/wiki/Neo-Nazism" title="Neo-Nazism">neo-Nazism</a>, invoking the history of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collaboration_in_German-occupied_Ukraine" title="Collaboration in German-occupied Ukraine">collaboration in German-occupied Ukraine</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abbruzzese_2022_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abbruzzese_2022-265">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-266">[261]</a></sup> and echoing an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antisemitic" title="Antisemitic">antisemitic</a> conspiracy theory that cast Russian Christians, rather than Jews, as the true victims of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Waxman_2022_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-Waxman_2022-267">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-animating_259-1"><a href="#cite_note-animating-259">[254]</a></sup> Ukraine does suffer a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Far-right" title="Far-right">far-right</a> fringe, including the neo-Nazi <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azov_Battalion" title="Azov Battalion">Azov Battalion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Right_Sector" title="Right Sector">Right Sector.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-266">[261]</a></sup> Analysts described Putin's rhetoric as greatly exaggerated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Li_Allen_Siemaszko_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-Li_Allen_Siemaszko-269">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abbruzzese_2022_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-Abbruzzese_2022-265">[260]</a></sup> The Poroshenko administration enforced the law <a href="/wiki/Decommunization_in_Ukraine" title="Decommunization in Ukraine">condemning the Soviet Union and the Nazis</a> in 2015. Zelenskyy, who is Jewish, stated that his grandfather served in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Soviet army</a> fighting against the Nazis;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[265]</a></sup> three of his family members died in <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Li_Allen_Siemaszko_269-1"><a href="#cite_note-Li_Allen_Siemaszko-269">[264]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russian_forces_near_Ukraine,_2021-12-03_(crop).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1912" data-file-width="2958" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg/220px-Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg/330px-Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg/440px-Russian_forces_near_Ukraine%2C_2021-12-03_%28crop%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Russian_forces_near_Ukraine,_2021-12-03_(crop).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A U.S. intelligence assessment map and imagery on Russian military movement nearby the Ukrainian border, as on 3 December 2021. It assessed that Russia had deployed about 70,000 military personnel mostly about 100200 kilometres (62124 mi) from the Ukrainian border, with an assessment this could be increased to 175,000 personnel. Published by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wp-20211203_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-wp-20211203-271">[266]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>During the second build-up, Russia issued demands to the US and NATO, insisting on a legally binding arrangement preventing Ukraine from ever joining NATO, and the removal of multinational forces stationed in NATO's Eastern European member states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[267]</a></sup> Russia threatened an unspecified military response if NATO continued to follow an "aggressive line".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[268]</a></sup> These demands were rejected by the US and NATO; new NATO members in <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a> had joined the alliance because their populations preferred the safety and economic opportunities offered by NATO and the EU, along with protection from Russian irredentism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[269]</a></sup> The demand for a formal treaty preventing Ukraine from joining NATO was rejected by Western officials as it would contravene the treaty's "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criteria_and_process_of_NATO_enlargement" title="Criteria and process of NATO enlargement">open door</a>" policy, although NATO made no efforts to comply with Ukraine's requests to join.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[270]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Preliminary_clashes_.2817.E2.80.9321_February.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Preliminary_clashes_(1721_February)">Preliminary clashes (1721 February)</span></h4>
<p>Fighting in Donbas escalated significantly from 17 February 2022 onwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[271]</a></sup> The Ukrainians and the Russian separatists each accused the other of attacks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[273]</a></sup> On 18 February, the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics ordered mandatory <a href="/wiki/Emergency_evacuation" title="Emergency evacuation">emergency evacuations</a> of civilians from their respective capital cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[276]</a></sup> although observers noted that full evacuations would take months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[277]</a></sup> Ukrainian media reported a sharp increase in artillery shelling by the separatists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Russian government intensified its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_disinformation" title="Russian disinformation">disinformation campaign</a>, with Russian state media promoting fabricated videos (<a href="/wiki/False_flag" title="False flag">false flags</a>) on a nearly hourly basis purporting to show Ukrainian forces attacking Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ViceDisinfo_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-ViceDisinfo-285">[280]</a></sup> Many of the disinformation videos were amateurish, and evidence showed that the claimed attacks, explosions, and evacuations in Donbas were staged by Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ViceDisinfo_285-1"><a href="#cite_note-ViceDisinfo-285">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[282]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Escalation_.2821.E2.80.9323_February.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Escalation_(2123_February)">Escalation (2123 February)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="3358" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="____2022-02-21.webm" height="124" id="mwe_player_0" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm/220px-seek%3D3-%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm.jpg" preload="none" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="586840" data-framerate="50" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b6/%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm/%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm.480p.vp9.webm"
