src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm&amp;lang=vi&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="vi" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label=" (zh-cn)" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm&amp;lang=zh-cn&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="zh-Hans-CN" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label=" (zh-hk)" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm&amp;lang=zh-hk&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="zh-Hant-HK" type="text/vtt"/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9E%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_2022-02-21.webm" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Putin's address to the nation on 21 February (English subtitles available)</div></div></div>
<p>On 21 February at 22:35 (UTC+3),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[283]</a></sup> Putin announced that the Russian government would <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatically_recognize" title="Diplomatically recognize">diplomatically recognize</a> the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[284]</a></sup> The same evening, Putin directed that Russian troops deploy into Donbas, in what Russia referred to as a "<a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> mission".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[286]</a></sup> The intervention was condemned by several members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a>; none voiced support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[287]</a></sup> On 22 February, the <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a> unanimously authorised Putin to use military force outside Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hodge_2022_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hodge_2022-293">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>In response, Zelenskyy ordered the conscription of army <a href="/wiki/Reservist" title="Reservist">reservists</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[289]</a></sup> The following day, Ukraine's parliament proclaimed a 30-day nationwide <a href="/wiki/State_of_emergency" title="State of emergency">state of emergency</a> and ordered the mobilisation of all reservists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[292]</a></sup> Russia began to evacuate its embassy in Kyiv.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[293]</a></sup> The websites of the Ukrainian parliament and government, along with banking websites, were hit by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/DDoS" title="DDoS">DDoS</a> attacks,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[294]</a></sup> widely attributed to Russian-backed hackers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the night of 23 February,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[297]</a></sup> Zelenskyy gave <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Zelensky%27s_emotional_appeal_to_Russians" title="s:Zelensky's emotional appeal to Russians">a speech</a> in Russian in which he appealed to the citizens of Russia to prevent war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[299]</a></sup> He rejected Russia's claims about neo-Nazis and stated that he had no intention of attacking the Donbas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[300]</a></sup> Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on 23 February that the separatist leaders in Donetsk and Luhansk had sent a letter to Putin stating that Ukrainian shelling had caused civilian deaths and appealing for military support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>In response, Ukraine requested an urgent UN Security Council meeting,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[302]</a></sup> which convened at 21:30 (UTC5).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[303]</a></sup> Half an hour into the emergency meeting, Putin announced the start of military operations in Ukraine. <a href="/wiki/Sergiy_Kyslytsya" title="Sergiy Kyslytsya">Sergiy Kyslytsya</a>, the Ukrainian representative, subsequently called on the Russian representative, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Nebenzya" title="Vasily Nebenzya">Vasily Nebenzya</a>, to "do everything possible to stop the war" or relinquish his position as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_the_UN_Security_Council" title="President of the UN Security Council">president of the UN Security Council</a>; Nebenzya refused.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2022_invasion">2022 invasion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Timeline of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Timeline of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif/220px-2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif/330px-2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif/440px-2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2022_Russian_Invasion_of_Ukraine_animated.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Animated map of Russia's invasion of Ukraine (click to play animation)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> began on the morning of 24 February,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[306]</a></sup> when Putin <a href="/wiki/On_conducting_a_special_military_operation" title="On conducting a special military operation">announced</a> a "special military operation" to "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demilitarise" title="Demilitarise">demilitarise</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denazification#Misuse_of_term" title="Denazification">denazify</a>" Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Waxman_20222_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-Waxman_20222-313">[308]</a></sup> Minutes later, missiles and <a href="/wiki/Airstrike" title="Airstrike">airstrikes</a> hit across Ukraine, including <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, shortly followed by a large ground invasion along multiple fronts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kirbyBBC_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-kirbyBBC-315">[310]</a></sup> Zelenskyy declared <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">martial law</a> and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_mobilisation" title="General mobilisation">general mobilisation</a> of all male Ukrainian citizens between 18 and 60, who were banned from leaving the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Interfax_2022_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-Interfax_2022-317">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian attacks were launched on a <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_offensive_(2022)" title="Kyiv offensive (2022)">northern front</a> from Belarus towards Kyiv, a <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_Ukraine_offensive" title="Northeastern Ukraine offensive">northeastern front</a> towards Kharkiv, a <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine_offensive" title="Southern Ukraine offensive">southern front</a> from Crimea, and a <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine_offensive" title="Eastern Ukraine offensive">southeastern front</a> from the cities of Luhansk and Donetsk.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBS-2022-03-202_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-2022-03-202-318">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBC-2022-03-212_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBC-2022-03-212-319">[314]</a></sup> During March, Ukraine stopped the Russian advance towards Kyiv. Amidst heavy losses and strong resistance, Russian troops retreated from Kyiv Oblast by 3 April. 
</p><p>On 8 April, Russia placed its forces in southern and eastern Ukraine under the command of General <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Dvornikov" title="Aleksandr Dvornikov">Aleksandr Dvornikov</a>, and some units withdrawn from the north were redeployed to the Donbas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hindustannewshub.com2_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-hindustannewshub.com2-320">[315]</a></sup> On 19 April, Russia launched a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Donbas_(2022)" title="Battle of Donbas (2022)">renewed attack</a> across a 500 kilometres (300 mi) long front extending from Kharkiv to Donetsk and Luhansk.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.com2_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com2-321">[316]</a></sup> By 13 May, a Ukraine counter-offensive had driven back Russian forces near Kharkiv. By 20 May, <a href="/wiki/Mariupol" title="Mariupol">Mariupol</a> fell to Russian troops following a prolonged <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Azovstal" title="Battle of Azovstal">siege</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Azovstal_iron_and_steel_works" title="Azovstal iron and steel works">Azovstal steel works</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p>The invasion was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reactions_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">internationally condemned</a> as a <a href="/wiki/War_of_aggression" title="War of aggression">war of aggression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[320]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_ES-11/1" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution ES-11/1">United Nations General Assembly resolution</a> demanded a full withdrawal of Russian forces, the <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a> ordered Russia to suspend military operations and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> expelled Russia. Many countries <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="International sanctions during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">imposed new sanctions</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Economic impact of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">affected the economies</a> of Russia and the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanctions_slams_Russian_economy_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sanctions_slams_Russian_economy-326">[321]</a></sup> and provided <a href="/wiki/List_of_foreign_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="List of foreign aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War">humanitarian and military aid to Ukraine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[322]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early June 2022, Ukrainian politician <a href="/wiki/Mykhailo_Podolyak" title="Mykhailo Podolyak">Mykhailo Podolyak</a> said that 100 to 200 Ukrainian soldiers were dying in combat every day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[323]</a></sup> Zelenskyy's military adviser <a href="/wiki/Oleksiy_Arestovych" title="Oleksiy Arestovych">Oleksiy Arestovych</a> said that up to 10,000 Ukrainian soldiers died in the first 100 days of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Violations_of_human_rights">Violations of human rights</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_situation_during_the_war_in_Donbas" title="Humanitarian situation during the war in Donbas">Humanitarian situation during the war in Donbas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_war_crimes#Ukraine" title="Russian war crimes">Russian war crimes  Ukraine</a></div>
<p>The war has been accompanied by violations of human rights. From 2014 to 2021, there were more than 3,000 civilian casualties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[325]</a></sup> The right of movement was impeded for the inhabitants of the conflict zone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unhr21_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-unhr21-331">[326]</a></sup> Arbitrary detention was practiced by both sides in the first years of the conflict. It decreased after 2016 in government-held areas, while in the separatist-held ones it continued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[327]</a></sup> The investigation into the abuses, including torture, committed by both sides made little progress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unhr21-2_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-unhr21-2-333">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[329]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights" title="Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights">OHCHR</a> the closure of three TV channels amounted to a violation of the freedom of expression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unhr21-2_333-1"><a href="#cite_note-unhr21-2-333">[328]</a></sup> There were cases of conflict-related sexual violence, however OHCHR believes that "there are no grounds to believe that sexual violence has been used for strategic or tactical ends by Government forces or the armed groups in the eastern regions of Ukraine."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[330]</a></sup> OHCHR estimates that from 2014 to 2021 around 4,000 detainees were subjected to torture and ill-treatment, approximately 1,500 by government actors and 2,500 by separatist armed groups, and reckons that around 340 of them were also victims of sexual violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Related_issues">Related issues</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gas_disputes">Gas disputes</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_gas_disputes" title="RussiaUkraine gas disputes">RussiaUkraine gas disputes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nord_Stream" title="Nord Stream">Nord Stream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nord_Stream_2" title="Nord Stream 2">Nord Stream 2</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">Russia in the European energy sector</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="807" data-file-width="771" decoding="async" height="262" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png/250px-Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png/375px-Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png/500px-Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Major_russian_gas_pipelines_to_europe.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Major Russian natural gas pipelines to Europe</div></div></div>
<p>Until 2014 Ukraine remains the main transit route for <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Russia" title="Natural gas in Russia">Russian natural gas</a> sold to Europe, which earned Ukraine about <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Dollar" title="US Dollar">$</a>3 billion a year in transit fees, making it the country's most lucrative export service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UkNGOSW15713_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-UkNGOSW15713-337">[332]</a></sup> Following Russia's launch of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nord_Stream_pipeline" title="Nord Stream pipeline">Nord Stream pipeline</a>, which bypasses Ukraine, gas transit volumes steadily decreased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UkNGOSW15713_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-UkNGOSW15713-337">[332]</a></sup> During the Russo-Ukrainian War, starting in February 2014 with the Russian annexation of Crimea, severe tensions extended to the gas sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[334]</a></sup> The outbreak of war in the Donbas region forced the suspension of a project to develop Ukraine's own <a href="/wiki/Shale_gas" title="Shale gas">shale gas</a> reserves at the <a href="/wiki/Yuzivska_gas_field" title="Yuzivska gas field">Yuzivska gas field</a>, which had been planned as a way to reduce Ukrainian dependence on Russian gas imports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fdg4_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-fdg4-340">[335]</a></sup> Eventually, the EU commissioner for energy <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCnther_Oettinger" title="Gnther Oettinger">Gnther Oettinger</a> was called in to broker a deal securing supplies to Ukraine and transit to the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>A terrorist explosion damaged Russia's <a href="/wiki/Urengoy%E2%80%93Pomary%E2%80%93Uzhhorod_pipeline" title="UrengoyPomaryUzhhorod pipeline">UrengoyPomaryUzhhorod pipeline</a> in Rozhniativ district in <a href="/wiki/Ivano-Frankivsk_Oblast" title="Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast">Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast</a>, Ukraine in May 2014.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Another section of the pipeline exploded in the <a href="/wiki/Poltava_Oblast" title="Poltava Oblast">Poltava Oblast</a> on 17 June 2014, one day after Russia limited the supply of gas to Ukrainian customers due to non-payment. Ukraine's Interior Minister <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arsen_Avakov_(politician)" title="Arsen Avakov (politician)">Arsen Avakov</a> said the following day that the explosion had been caused by a bomb.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia planned to completely abandon <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">gas supplies to Europe</a> through Ukraine after 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[339]</a></sup> Russia's state-owned energy giant <a href="/wiki/Gazprom" title="Gazprom">Gazprom</a> had already substantially reduced the volumes of gas transited across Ukraine, and expressed its intention to reduce the level further by means of transit diversification pipelines (Turkish Stream, Nord Stream, etc.).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[340]</a></sup> Gazprom and Ukraine agreed to a five-year deal on Russian gas transit to Europe at the end of 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[342]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, the <a href="/wiki/TurkStream" title="TurkStream">TurkStream</a> natural gas pipeline running from Russia to <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> changed the regional gas flows in South-East Europe by diverting the <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_transmission_system_of_Ukraine" title="Natural gas transmission system of Ukraine">transit through Ukraine</a> and the Trans Balkan Pipeline system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sabah231019_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-sabah231019-348">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[344]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Joe_Biden" title="Presidency of Joe Biden">Biden administration</a> waived Trump's <a href="/wiki/Countering_America%27s_Adversaries_Through_Sanctions_Act" title="Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act">CAATSA sanctions</a> on the company behind Russia's <a href="/wiki/Nord_Stream_2" title="Nord Stream 2">Nord Stream 2</a> gas pipeline to Germany and its chief executive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[346]</a></sup> Ukrainian President Zelenskyy said he was "surprised" and "disappointed" by <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>'s decision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[347]</a></sup> In July 2021, the U.S. urged Ukraine not to criticise a forthcoming agreement with Germany over the pipeline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsj-20210720_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsj-20210720-354">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 20 July 2021, Joe Biden and German Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> concluded a deal that the U.S. might trigger sanctions if Russia used Nord Stream as a "political weapon". The deal aimed to prevent Poland and Ukraine from being cut off from Russian gas supplies. Ukraine will get a $50 million loan for green technology until 2024 and Germany will set up a billion dollar fund to promote Ukraine's transition to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Green_energy" title="Green energy">green energy</a> to compensate for the loss of the gas transit fees. The contract for transiting Russian gas through Ukraine will be prolonged until 2034, if the Russian government agrees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[350]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ft-20210721_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-ft-20210721-357">[352]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2021, Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy" title="Volodymyr Zelenskyy">Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> warned that the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline between Russia and Germany was "a dangerous weapon, not only for Ukraine but for the whole of Europe."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[353]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[354]</a></sup> In September 2021, Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Naftogaz" title="Naftogaz">Naftogaz</a> CEO <a href="/wiki/Yuriy_Vitrenko" title="Yuriy Vitrenko">Yuriy Vitrenko</a> accused Russia of using <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural" title="Natural">natural</a> gas as a "geopolitical weapon".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[355]</a></sup> Vitrenko stated that "A joint statement from the United States and Germany said that if the Kremlin used gas as a weapon, there would be an appropriate response. We are now waiting for the imposition of sanctions on a 100% subsidiary of Gazprom, the operator of Nord Stream 2."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hybrid_warfare">Hybrid warfare</span></h3>
<p>The Russo-Ukrainian conflict has also included elements of <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_warfare" title="Hybrid warfare">hybrid warfare</a> using non-traditional means. <a href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Ukrainian_cyberwarfare" title="RussianUkrainian cyberwarfare">Cyberwarfare</a> has been used by <a href="/wiki/Cyberwarfare_by_Russia" title="Cyberwarfare by Russia">Russia</a> in operations including the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_power_grid_hack" title="Ukraine power grid hack">Ukraine power grid hack</a> in December 2015 and 2016, which was the first successful cyber attack on a power grid,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-texty.17_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-texty.17-362">[357]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_cyberattacks_on_Ukraine" title="2017 cyberattacks on Ukraine">Mass hacker supply-chain attack</a> in June 2017, which the US claimed was the largest known cyber attack.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wh.2018-02-15_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-wh.2018-02-15-363">[358]</a></sup> In retaliation, Ukrainian operations have included the <a href="/wiki/Surkov_leaks" title="Surkov leaks">Surkov Leaks</a> in October 2016 which released 2,337 e-mails in relation to Russian plans for seizing Crimea from Ukraine and fomenting separatist unrest in Donbas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-364">[359]</a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/Russian_information_war_against_Ukraine" title="Russian information war against Ukraine">Russian information war against Ukraine</a> has been another front of hybrid warfare waged by Russia.
</p><p>A Russian <a href="/wiki/Fifth_column" title="Fifth column">fifth column</a> in Ukraine has also been claimed to exist among the <a href="/wiki/Party_of_Regions" title="Party of Regions">Party of Regions</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Ukraine" title="Communist Party of Ukraine">Communist Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Progressive_Socialist_Party_of_Ukraine" title="Progressive Socialist Party of Ukraine">Progressive Socialist Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_propaganda_and_disinformation_campaigns">Russian propaganda and disinformation campaigns</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_information_war_against_Ukraine" title="Russian information war against Ukraine">Russian information war against Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_disinformation_in_the_post-Soviet_era" title="Russian disinformation in the post-Soviet era">Russian disinformation in the post-Soviet era</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="678" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg/220px-%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg/330px-%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg/440px-%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B2%D1%8C%D1%8E_%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%92%D0%93%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%9A_02.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pro-Kremlin TV and radio host <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vladimir_Solovyov_(journalist)" title="Vladimir Solovyov (journalist)">Vladimir Solovyov</a> voiced support for his country's invasion of Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[363]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>False stories have been used to provoke public outrage during the war. In April 2014, Russian news channels <a href="/wiki/Russia-1" title="Russia-1">Russia-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/NTV_(Russia)" title="NTV (Russia)">NTV</a> showed a man saying he was attacked by a fascist Ukrainian gang on one channel and on the other channel saying he was funding the training of right-wing anti-Russia radicals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Russia_and_the_Menace_of_Unreality_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-Russia_and_the_Menace_of_Unreality-370">[365]</a></sup> A third segment portrayed the man as a neo-Nazi surgeon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[366]</a></sup> In May 2014, Russia-1 aired a story about Ukrainian atrocities using footage of a 2012 Russian operation in <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasian_Federal_District" title="North Caucasian Federal District">North Caucasus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putins_Pal_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Putins_Pal-372">[367]</a></sup> In the same month, the Russian news network <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_(news_agency,_Russia)" title="Life (news agency, Russia)">Life</a> presented a 2013 photograph of a wounded child in Syria as a victim of Ukrainian troops who had just retaken <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_International_Airport" title="Donetsk International Airport">Donetsk International Airport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2014, several Russian state news outlets reported that Ukraine was using <a href="/wiki/White_phosphorus_munitions" title="White phosphorus munitions">white phosphorus</a> using 2004 footage of white phosphorus being used by the United States in Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putins_Pal_372-1"><a href="#cite_note-Putins_Pal-372">[367]</a></sup> In July 2014, <a href="/wiki/Channel_One_Russia" title="Channel One Russia">Channel One Russia</a> broadcast an interview with a woman who said that <a href="/wiki/Crucified_boy" title="Crucified boy">a 3-year-old boy who spoke Russian</a> was crucified by Ukrainian nationalists in a fictitious square in <a href="/wiki/Sloviansk" title="Sloviansk">Sloviansk</a> that turned out to be false.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Russia_and_the_Menace_of_Unreality_370-1"><a href="#cite_note-Russia_and_the_Menace_of_Unreality-370">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Putins_Pal_372-2"><a href="#cite_note-Putins_Pal-372">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2022, Russian state media told stories of genocide and mass graves full of ethnic Russians in eastern Ukraine. One set of graves outside <a href="/wiki/Luhansk" title="Luhansk">Luhansk</a> was dug when intense fighting in 2014 cut off the electricity in the local morgue. Amnesty International investigated 2014 Russian claims of mass graves filled with hundreds of bodies and instead found isolated incidents of extrajudicial executions by both sides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-377">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Russian censorship apparatus <i><a href="/wiki/Roskomnadzor" title="Roskomnadzor">Roskomnadzor</a></i> ordered the country's media to employ information only from Russian state sources or face fines and blocks,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[374]</a></sup> and ordered media and schools to describe the war as a "special military operation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[375]</a></sup> On 4 March 2022, Putin signed into law a bill introducing <a href="/wiki/Russian_2022_war_censorship_laws" title="Russian 2022 war censorship laws">prison sentences of up to 15 years</a> for those who publish "fake news" about the Russian military and its operations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[376]</a></sup> leading to some media outlets to stop reporting on Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[377]</a></sup> Russia's opposition politician <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Navalny" title="Alexei Navalny">Alexei Navalny</a> said the "monstrosity of lies" in the <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Russia" title="Mass media in Russia">Russian state media</a> "is unimaginable. And, unfortunately, so is its persuasiveness for those who have no access to alternative information."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[378]</a></sup> He tweeted that "warmongers" among Russian state media personalities "should be treated as war criminals. From the editors-in-chief to the talk show hosts to the news editors, [they] should be sanctioned now and tried someday."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Putin and Russian media have described the government of Ukraine as being led by neo-Nazis persecuting ethnic Russians who are in need of protection by Russia, despite Ukraine's President Zelenskyy being <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-377">[372]</a></sup> According to journalist Natalia Antonova, "Russias present-day war of aggression is refashioned by propaganda into a direct continuation of the legacy of the millions of Russian soldiers who died to stop" <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[382]</a></sup> Ukraine's rejection of the adoption of Russia-initiated General Assembly resolutions on combating the glorification of <a href="/wiki/Nazism" title="Nazism">Nazism</a>, the latest iteration of which is General Assembly Resolution A/C.3/76/L.57/Rev.1 on <i>Combating Glorification of Nazism, Neo-Nazism and other Practices that Contribute to Fueling Contemporary Forms of Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia and Related Intolerance</i>, serve to present Ukraine as a pro-Nazi state, and indeed likely forms the basis for Russia's claims, with the only other state rejecting the adoption of the resolution being the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[384]</a></sup> The Deputy US Representative for <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_and_Social_Council" title="United Nations Economic and Social Council">ECOSOC</a> describes such resolutions as "thinly veiled attempts to legitimize Russian disinformation campaigns denigrating neighboring nations and promoting the distorted Soviet narrative of much of contemporary European history, using the cynical guise of halting Nazi glorification".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[385]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Russia.E2.80.93NATO_relations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="RussiaNATO_relations">RussiaNATO relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="RussiaNATO relations">RussiaNATO relations</a></div>
<p>Russian military aircraft flying over the Baltic and Black Seas often do not indicate their position or communicate with air traffic controllers, thus posing a potential risk to civilian airliners. NATO aircraft scrambled many times in late April 2022 in order to track and intercept these aircraft near alliance airspace. The Russian aircraft intercepted never entered NATO airspace, and the interceptions were conducted in a safe and routine manner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[386]</a></sup> Although Russian Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Lavrov" title="Sergey Lavrov">Sergey Lavrov</a> has characterized the conflict as a <a href="/wiki/Proxy_war" title="Proxy war">proxy war</a> instigated by NATO,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[387]</a></sup> he said: "We dont think were at war with NATO ... Unfortunately, NATO believes it is at war with Russia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[388]</a></sup> British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Boris_Johnson" title="Boris Johnson">Boris Johnson</a> rejected Lavrov's allegation that NATO is fighting a 'proxy war' in Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Reactions">Reactions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Second_Cold_War" title="Second Cold War">Second Cold War</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reactions_to_the_annexation_of_Crimea">Reactions to the annexation of Crimea</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="International reactions to the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">International reactions to the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ukrainian_response">Ukrainian response</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg/220px-%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg/330px-%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg/440px-%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE-%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%8B%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Following Russia's annexation of Crimea, Ukraine blocked the <a href="/wiki/North_Crimean_Canal" title="North Crimean Canal">North Crimean Canal</a>, which provided 85% of Crimea's drinking and irrigation water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[390]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Interim Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Oleksandr_Turchynov" title="Oleksandr Turchynov">Oleksandr Turchynov</a> accused Russia of "provoking a conflict" by backing the seizure of the Crimean parliament building and other government offices on the Crimean peninsula. He compared Russia's military actions to the 2008 <a href="/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War" title="Russo-Georgian War">Russo-Georgian War</a>, when Russian troops occupied parts of the <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Republic of Georgia</a> and the breakaway enclaves of <a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Abkhazia</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Ossetia" title="South Ossetia">South Ossetia</a> were established under the control of Russian-backed administrations. He called on Putin to withdraw Russian troops from Crimea and stated that Ukraine will "preserve its territory" and "defend its independence".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[391]</a></sup> On 1 March, he warned, "Military intervention would be the beginning of war and the end of any relations between Ukraine and Russia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[392]</a></sup> On 1 March, Acting President Oleksandr Turchynov placed the Armed Forces of Ukraine on full alert and combat readiness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Temporarily_Occupied_Territories_and_IDPs" title="Ministry of Temporarily Occupied Territories and IDPs">Ministry of Temporarily Occupied Territories and IDPs</a> was established by Ukrainian government on 20 April 2016 to manage occupied parts of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporarily_occupied_and_uncontrolled_territories_of_Ukraine_(2014-present)" title="Temporarily occupied and uncontrolled territories of Ukraine (2014-present)">Donetsk, Luhansk and Crimea</a> regions affected by Russian military intervention of 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NMC20416_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-NMC20416-399">[394]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="NATO_and_United_States_military_response">NATO and United States military response</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Operation_Atlantic_Resolve" title="Operation Atlantic Resolve">Operation Atlantic Resolve</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Deterrence_Initiative" title="European Deterrence Initiative">European Deterrence Initiative</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO_Enhanced_Forward_Presence" title="NATO Enhanced Forward Presence">NATO Enhanced Forward Presence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="RussiaNATO relations">RussiaNATO relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_(16999448822).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg/220px-2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg/330px-2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg/440px-2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_%2816999448822%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2CR_returns_home_to_Vilseck_(16999448822).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A U.S. Army convoy in <a href="/wiki/Vilseck" title="Vilseck">Vilseck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> during <a href="/wiki/Operation_Atlantic_Resolve" title="Operation Atlantic Resolve">Operation Atlantic Resolve</a>, NATO's efforts to reassert its military presence in central and eastern Europe that began in April 2014.</div></div></div>
<p>On 4 March 2014, the United States pledged $1 billion in aid to Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[395]</a></sup> Russia's actions increased tensions in nearby countries historically within its <a href="/wiki/Sphere_of_influence" title="Sphere of influence">sphere of influence</a>, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>. All have large Russian-speaking populations, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_presence_in_Transnistria" title="Russian military presence in Transnistria">Russian troops are stationed</a> in the breakaway Moldovan territory of <a href="/wiki/Transnistria" title="Transnistria">Transnistria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herald_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herald-401">[396]</a></sup> Some devoted resources to increasing defensive capabilities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NTI_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-NTI-402">[397]</a></sup> and many requested increased support from the U.S. and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a>, which they had joined in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herald_401-1"><a href="#cite_note-Herald-401">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NTI_402-1"><a href="#cite_note-NTI-402">[397]</a></sup> The conflict "reinvigorated" NATO, which had been created to face the Soviet Union, but had devoted more resources to "expeditionary missions" in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gearan_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gearan-403">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to diplomatic support in its conflict with Russia, the U.S. provided Ukraine with US$1.5 billion in military aid during the 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[399]</a></sup> In 2018 the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">U.S. House of Representatives</a> passed a provision blocking any training of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azov_Battalion" title="Azov Battalion">Azov Battalion</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Territorial_defense_battalions_(Ukraine)" title="Territorial defense battalions (Ukraine)">Ukrainian National Guard</a> by American forces. In previous years, between 2014 and 2017, the U.S. House of Representatives passed amendments banning support of Azov, but due to pressure from the <a href="/wiki/The_Pentagon" title="The Pentagon">Pentagon</a>, the amendments were quietly lifted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[402]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial_markets">Financial markets</span></h4>
<p>The initial reaction to the escalation of tensions in Crimea caused the Russian and European stock market to tumble.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[403]</a></sup>
The intervention caused the Swiss franc to climb to a 2-year high against the dollar and 1-year high against the Euro. The Euro and the US dollar both rose, as did the Australian dollar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20140303reuters_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-20140303reuters-409">[404]</a></sup> The Russian stock market declined by more than 10 percent, while the Russian <a href="/wiki/Ruble" title="Ruble">ruble</a> hit all-time lows against the US dollar and the Euro.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIRDIU_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-WIRDIU-410">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20140303aphosted_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-20140303aphosted-412">[407]</a></sup> The Russian central bank hiked interest rates and intervened in the foreign exchange markets to the tune of $12 billion<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2022)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> to try to stabilize its currency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20140303reuters_409-1"><a href="#cite_note-20140303reuters-409">[404]</a></sup> Prices for wheat and grain rose, with Ukraine being a major exporter of both crops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>Later in March 2014, the reaction of the financial markets to the Crimea annexation was surprisingly mellow, with global financial markets rising immediately after the referendum held in Crimea, one explanation being that the sanctions were already priced in following the earlier Russian incursion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[409]</a></sup>
Other observers considered that the positive reaction of the global financial markets on Monday 17 March 2014, after the announcement of sanctions against Russia by the EU and the US, revealed that these sanctions were too weak to hurt Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[410]</a></sup>
In early August 2014, the German <a href="/wiki/DAX" title="DAX">DAX</a> was down by 6 percent for the year, and 11 percent since June, over concerns Russia, Germany's 13th biggest trade partner, would retaliate against sanctions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SanctionsGermany_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-SanctionsGermany-416">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reactions_to_the_intervention_in_Donbas">Reactions to the intervention in Donbas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_war_in_Donbas" title="International reactions to the war in Donbas">International reactions to the war in Donbas</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2079" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg/330px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg/440px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88_%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B2%D0%B0_21_%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82_2014_L1450559.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Peace march in <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, 21 September 2014</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg/220px-2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg/330px-2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg/440px-2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014-12-20._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8_054.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pro-Russian supporters in <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, 20 December 2014</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ukrainian_public_opinion">Ukrainian public opinion</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Putin_khuylo!" title="Putin khuylo!">Putin khuylo!</a></div>
<p>A poll of the Ukrainian public, excluding Russian-annexed <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, was taken by the <a href="/wiki/International_Republican_Institute" title="International Republican Institute">International Republican Institute</a> from 12 to 25 September 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRI14OCT_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-IRI14OCT-417">[412]</a></sup> 89% of those polled opposed 2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine. As broken down by region, 78% of those polled from <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Dnipropetrovsk_Oblast" title="Dnipropetrovsk Oblast">Dnipropetrovsk Oblast</a>) opposed said intervention, along with 89% in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine" title="Southern Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>, 93% in <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, and 99% in <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRI14OCT_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-IRI14OCT-417">[412]</a></sup> As broken down by native language, 79% of Russian speakers and 95% of Ukrainian speakers opposed the intervention. 80% of those polled said the country should remain a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRI14OCT_417-2"><a href="#cite_note-IRI14OCT-417">[412]</a></sup>
</p><p>A poll of the <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimean</a> public in Russian-annexed Crimea was taken by the Ukrainian branch of Germany's biggest market research organization, <a href="/wiki/GfK" title="GfK">GfK</a>, on 1622 January 2015. According to its results: "Eighty-two percent of those polled said they fully supported Crimea's inclusion in Russia, and another 11 percent expressed partial support. Only 4 percent spoke out against it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>A joint poll conducted by Levada and the <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_International_Institute_of_Sociology" title="Kyiv International Institute of Sociology">Kyiv International Institute of Sociology</a> from September to October 2020 found that in the breakaway regions controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">DPR</a>/<a href="/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic" title="Luhansk People's Republic">LNR</a>, just over half of the respondents wanted to join Russia (either with or without some autonomous status) while less than one-tenth wanted independence and 12% wanted reintegration into Ukraine. It contrasted with respondents in Kyiv-controlled Donbas, where a vast majority felt the separatist regions should be returned to Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[416]</a></sup> According to results from Levada in January 2022, roughly 70% of those in the breakaway regions said their territories should become part of the Russian Federation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_public_opinion">Russian public opinion</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2014_anti-war_protests_in_Russia" title="2014 anti-war protests in Russia">2014 anti-war protests in Russia</a></div>
<p>An August 2014 survey by the <a href="/wiki/Levada_Center" title="Levada Center">Levada Centre</a> reported that only 13% of those Russians polled would support the Russian government in an open war with Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[418]</a></sup> Street protests against the war in Ukraine arose in Russia. Notable protests first occurred in March<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afp_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-afp-425">[420]</a></sup> and large protests occurred in September when "tens of thousands" protested the war in Ukraine with a peace march in downtown Moscow on Sunday, 21 September 2014, "under heavy police supervision".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wp20140921_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-wp20140921-426">[421]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reactions_to_the_full-scale_invasion_of_Ukraine">Reactions to the full-scale invasion of Ukraine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reactions_to_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Reactions to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_foreign_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="List of foreign aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War">List of foreign aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ukrainian_public_opinion_2">Ukrainian public opinion</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2957" data-file-width="4433" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg/220px-02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg/330px-02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg/440px-02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:02022_1199_Refugees_from_Ukraine_in_Krak%C3%B3w.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/2022_Ukrainian_refugee_crisis" title="2022 Ukrainian refugee crisis">Ukrainian refugees</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Krakw">Krakw</a> protest against the war, 6 March 2022</div></div></div>
<p>In March 2022, a week after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, 98% of Ukrainians  including 82% of <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Ukraine" title="Russians in Ukraine">ethnic Russians</a> living in Ukraine  said they did not believe that any part of Ukraine was rightfully part of Russia, according to <a href="/wiki/Michael_Ashcroft" title="Michael Ashcroft">Lord Ashcroft</a>'s polls which did not include Crimea and the separatist-controlled part of Donbas. 97% of Ukrainians said they had an unfavourable view of Russian President Vladimir Putin, with a further 94% saying they had an unfavourable view of the Russian Armed Forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_public_opinion_2">Russian public opinion</span></h4>
<p>An April 2022 survey by the Levada Centre reported that approximately 74% of the Russians polled supported the "special military operation" in Ukraine, suggesting that Russian public opinion has shifted considerably since 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[423]</a></sup> According to some sources, a reason many Russians supported the "special military operation" has to do with the <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_in_Russia" title="Propaganda in Russia">propaganda</a> and disinformation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[425]</a></sup> In addition, it has been suggested that some respondents did not want to answer pollsters' questions for fear of negative consequences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[427]</a></sup> At the end of March, a poll conducted in Russia by the Levada Center concluded the following: When asked why they think the military operation is taking place, respondents said it was to protect and defend civilians, ethnic Russians or Russian speakers in Ukraine (43%), to prevent an attack on Russia (25%), to get rid of nationalists and denazify Ukraine (21%), and to incorporate Ukraine and/or the Donbas region into Russia (3%)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h4>
<p>On 28 April 2022, US President <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> asked <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> for an additional $33 billion to assist Ukraine, including $20 billion to provide weapons to Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[429]</a></sup> On 5 May, Ukraine's Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Denys_Shmyhal" title="Denys Shmyhal">Denys Shmyhal</a> announced that Ukraine had received more than $12 billion worth of weapons and financial aid from Western countries since the start of Russia's invasion on 24 February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[430]</a></sup> On 21 May 2022, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> passed legislation providing $40 billion in new military and humanitarian foreign aid to Ukraine, marking a historically large commitment of funds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[432]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For further details, see <a href="/wiki/Belarusian_involvement_in_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Belarusian involvement in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">Belarusian involvement in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There remain "some contradictions and inherent problems" regarding the date on which the annexation began.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disunited_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-Disunited-2">[1]</a></sup> Ukraine claims 20 February 2014 as "the beginning of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporarily_occupied_and_uncontrolled_territories_of_Ukraine" title="Temporarily occupied and uncontrolled territories of Ukraine">temporary occupation of Crimea and Sevastopol by Russia</a>", citing the timeframe inscribed on the Russian <a href="/wiki/Medal_%22For_the_Return_of_Crimea%22" title='Medal "For the Return of Crimea"'>medal "For the Return of Crimea"</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[2]</a></sup> and in 2015 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ukrainian_parliament" title="Ukrainian parliament">Ukrainian parliament</a> officially designated the date as such.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[3]</a></sup> On 20 February 2014, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Konstantinov_(politician)" title="Vladimir Konstantinov (politician)">Vladimir Konstantinov</a> who at that time was a chairman of the republican council of Crimea and representing the <a href="/wiki/Party_of_Regions" title="Party of Regions">Party of Regions</a> expressed his thoughts about secession of the region from Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup> On 23 February 2014 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embassy_of_Russia_in_Kyiv" title="Embassy of Russia in Kyiv">Russian ambassador to Ukraine</a> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Zurabov" title="Mikhail Zurabov">Mikhail Zurabov</a> was recalled to Moscow due to a "worsening of [the] situation in Ukraine". In early March 2015, President Putin stated in a <a href="/wiki/Crimea._The_Way_Home" title="Crimea. The Way Home">Russian movie about the annexation of Crimea</a> that he ordered the operation to "restore" Crimea to Russia following an all-night emergency meeting on 2223 February 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disunited_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-Disunited-2">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yahoo_News_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yahoo_News-6">[5]</a></sup> and in 2018 the Russian Foreign Minister claimed that the earlier "start date" on the medal was due to a "technical misunderstanding".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Includes 400500 Russian servicemen (<a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">US</a> claim, March 2015)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bellal2016_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bellal2016-18">[16]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru">p- </span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Russian-language romanization"><i lang="ru-Latn">rossiysko-ukrainskaya voyna</i></span>; <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">- </span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian" title="Romanization of Ukrainian">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Ukrainian-language romanization"><i lang="uk-Latn">rosiisko-ukrainska viina</i></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many countries have provided various levels of support to Ukraine short of becoming belligerents in the war, while <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> has provided Russian forces territorial access for the 2022 invasion.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">

<li id="cite_note-Disunited-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Disunited_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Disunited_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation book cs1" (2016). <a class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/11853815" rel="nofollow">"Brothers Disunited: Russia's use of military power in Ukraine"</a>.  In Black, J.L.; Johns, Michael (eds.). <i>The Return of the Cold War: Ukraine, the West and Russia</i>. London. pp. 99129. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.4324%2F9781315684567-5" rel="nofollow">10.4324/9781315684567-5</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-138-92409-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-138-92409-3"><bdi>978-1-138-92409-3</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/909325250" rel="nofollow">909325250</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Brothers+Disunited%3A+Russia%27s+use+of+military+power+in+Ukraine&amp;rft.btitle=The+Return+of+the+Cold+War%3A+Ukraine%2C+the+West+and+Russia&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=99-129&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F909325250&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4324%2F9781315684567-5&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-138-92409-3&amp;rft.aulast=McDermott&amp;rft.aufirst=Roger+N.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.academia.edu%2F11853815&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARusso-Ukrainian+War"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/PV.7683&amp;Lang=E" rel="nofollow">"7683rd meeting of the United Nations Security Council. Thursday, 28 April 2016, 3 p.m. New York"</a>. <q>Mr. Prystaiko (Ukraine): ... In that regard, I have to remind the Council that the official medal that was produced by the Russian Federation for the so-called return of Crimea has the dates on it, starting with 20 February, which is the day before that agreement was brought to the attention of the Security Council by the representative of the Russian Federation. Therefore, the Russian Federation started  not just planned, but started  the annexation of Crimea the day before we reached the first agreement and while President Yanukovych was still in power.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=7683rd+meeting+of+the+United+Nations+Security+Council.+Thursday%2C+28+April+2016%2C+3+p.m.+New+York&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fga%2Fsearch%2Fview_doc.asp%3Fsymbol%3DS%2FPV.7683%26Lang%3DE&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARusso-Ukrainian+War"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a class="external text" href="https://www.segodnya.ua/ua/regions/krym/nyasha-poklonskaya-obeshchaet-boycam-berkuta-nakazat-uchastnikov-maydana-700800.html" rel="nofollow">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>''    ''   "</a>. <i>www.segodnya.ua</i> (in Ukrainian)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 February</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.segodnya.ua&amp;rft.atitle=%27%D0%9D%D1%8F%D1%88%D0%B0%27+%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0+%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%96%D1%86%D1%8F%D1%94+%D0%B1%D1%96%D0%B9%D1%86%D1%8F%D0%BC+%27%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B0%27+%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8+%D1%83%D1%87%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D1%96%D0%B2+%D0%9C%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%83&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.segodnya.ua%2Fua%2Fregions%2Fkrym%2Fnyasha-poklonskaya-obeshchaet-boycam-berkuta-nakazat-uchastnikov-maydana-700800.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARusso-Ukrainian+War"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://eng.ombudsman-dnr.ru/the-overview-of-the-current-social-and-humanitarian-situation-in-the-territory-of-the-donetsk-peoples-republic-as-a-result-of-hostilities-between-23-and-29-january-2021/" rel="nofollow">"The overview of the current social and humanitarian situation in the territory of the Donetsk People's Republic as a result of hostilities between 23 and 29 January 2021"</a>.
